APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Department of Indian Affairs may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name:
Age:
Name of Band:
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid:
Father's full name and No.:
Mother's full name and No.:
Parents living or dead:
State of child's health:
Religion:
Does applicant speak English?
Previously attended:
school for years.

(Signature of Father)

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Agent

Note—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Ottawa, May 30, 1944.

Rev. Sister Souka, Principal, Providence Mission Indian Residential School, Fort Providence, N.W.T.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return of the Providence Mission School, we note that No. 256 Maurice Nicholas died January 13, 1944. Thirteen days have been requested. If this child died in school, it is requested that you make a full report on Form 414 and return it to this office.

With reference to the last paragraph of Departmental letter of February 25th, we note that Vera and Mabel Edwards and Thos. Ezza are still on the Quarterly Return. They should be returned to their homes immediately.

Philip Phelan,

Fort Providence, N.W.T.
June 17th, 1944.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of May 3rd was received today.

I wish to inform you that the report form #14 for Maurice Nicholas, who died at school was made out and forwarded to the Indian Agent last January.

I regret to say that the Departmental letter of February 25th was not received at this school. Therefore you will easily understand why the children were maintained on the report and still are. If they are obliged to leave the school we must wait for means of transportation.

I would appreciate details regarding their discharge.

Sincerely,

Sister Mary Mack.
Ottawa, July 8, 1944.

Dear Sister Mack:

With reference to your letter of June 17, it is noted that Form 414 for Maurice Nicholas has been forwarded to the Indian Agent.

I note that you did not receive our letter of February 25. On reviewing our file, I find that this letter was directed to Dr. Truesdell, Indian Agent, Fort Simpson, N.W.T., and evidently he did not bring it to your attention. The main item in our letter of February 25 was our statement regarding Vera and Mabel Edwards and Thomas Ezea. The application forms submitted for these children showed that their religion is Anglican. Under these circumstances, they are not eligible for admission to the Providence Mission Residential School and their names should not appear on future returns from your school. No grant will be provided for them.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend Sister Mary Mack,
Providence Indian Residential School,
Fort Providence, N. W. T.

Dear Sister:

The Department is in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P., with reference to the death of Baptiste Bonnet-Rouge (Menicoche). The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

My dear Mr. Phelan,

In a letter dated December 7th, 1944, Reverend Father Michel, principal of the above school, informs me that the Department has refused to allow the grant for three children who have been in this school for a year and a half. These children are Mabel and Vera Edwards, and Tommy Azéa. In view of the circumstances and facts related by Father Michel, I think that it would be possible to review the case of these three children and to allow grant for them, at least for the time that they have been in school.

Here are the facts concerning these three children. Absolutely nothing was done by either the principal or by the Sister Superior of the school to recruit Mabel and Vera Edwards as they were brought to the school - or at least sent to it - by your Doctor-Agent Truesdell. Tommy Azéa was placed in school by his own mother. Apparently, the reason why the Doctor sent these two children to Providence although they were Protestants is that there is no Protestant school within eight hundred miles of Fort Simpson: this is the C.E. school at Aklavik; and moreover, that they are semi-orphans as their mother is dead. Tommy is an illegitimate child and it is stated that his mother can not take care of him as she is working as a servant for an American trapper. Edwards, the father of Vera and Mabel, had two daughters by his first wife, one of whom Elsie is now in the Providence school. A short time after the birth of the second daughter, Edwards separated from his first wife and took a second wife, this time a Protestant, but without the benefit of marriage. It is this second wife who is the mother of Mabel and Vera who were both baptized Protestants as their mother had been. The latter died at Fort Simpson last year. It was after the death of the mother that Dr. Truesdell decided to send these two girls to our school as there was no Protestant school in the region. It is possible that Dr. Truesdell decided to take these two girls away from their father because he felt that they were not morally secure in his care.
Father Michel concludes his letter as follows: "If the Department wishes to adhere to its decision not to allow grant for these children in the Providence school, let it indicate to us where they have to be sent; as we only accepted them on the recommendation of the agent. If the Department wishes to send them to Aklavik and pay their transportation thereto, we are ready to send them there; but in view of the orphan condition of these children, it is not enough to merely say that their names are not to appear on our school reports. There is no one to take care of these children, and we certainly can not put them out to die of cold and starvation.

Will you please let me know your final decision as I have promised Father Michel to write to him with the least delay possible.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J. Crea was accepted in Providence at the request of his mother, who signed an application to that effect.
Ottawa, January 18, 1945.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, I checked our returns and find that the per capita allowance was paid for Mabel Edwards No. 0289; Vera Edwards No. 0290 and Tommy Asea No. 261 to March 31, 1944. No grant was paid for these children for the June and September quarters, 1944.

In view of the contents of your letter, which indicates that these children were placed in the school at the express wish of the Indian agent and the further fact that it is impossible to transfer them at the present time, owing to weather conditions, it has been decided to allow grant for them from July 1, 1944, to June 30, 1945. In preparing the December quarter return of the Providence Mission Residential School, grant should be requested for each of these children for 184 days, namely, for the September and December quarters of 1944.

It is our intention to communicate with the Indian agent regarding these children, and their case will be reviewed at the end of June.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, January 18, 1945.

Dr. W.A.M. Truesdell,
Indian Agent, Fort Simpson, N.W.T.

I desire to refer you to our letter of February 25, 1944, regarding Vera Edwards, Mabel Edwards and Thomas Ezea. The application forms stated that these children were Anglican and you were then informed that we could not consider their admission as grant-earning pupils to the Providence Mission Residential School.

We received no reply to that letter and from a communication just received it appears that the children were placed in that school at your request, and no attempt has been made to secure other accommodation for them. The information received from our correspondent regarding the religious affiliation of the two Edwards girls is rather doubtful. It is our intention to allow grant for these children to the end of June, in order to give us time to review their status. I wish you would obtain further information regarding all three, especially regarding their religious affiliations and let us have a letter from you as soon as convenient.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Fort Simpson, N.W.T. May 3, 1945.

Referring to your letter of February 2nd, 1945, I beg to say that the girl you mentioned—Angelique Bonnet Rouge—was bereaved by the death of her father last October and had no home to which she could go at the time, and on advice received from the Father Superior of the Fort Providence Residential School and also the Constable in charge of the R.C.M.P. at Providence, I deemed it best that she be admitted to the school until some other provision could be made for her care. She is not very strong, but shows no sign of Tuberculosis, and I believe that regular meals of a nourishing type will soon build her strength up again. I believe she was living a very precarious existence before her admission, as they had very little food in the house, as the father was the mainstay of their existence and without him very little support for the family was available and only that through the generosity of neighbors. This girl had had very little previous schooling and is showing a very commendable eagerness to obtain some education. In the summer during my Annuity paying visit to Providence, I will endeavor to obtain a home for this girl with another family, but until that time I believe she should remain at the school.

I have notified the Principal of the school of the error in using the wrong number of days in December quarter and also have notified her to show date of admission to school exactly and of her failure to show this on her December return.

W.A.M. Truesdell,
Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Referring to your letter of January 18th, 1945, re the two Edwards children and Thomas Ezea—the latter should be Isaiah—as in our Treaty Book.

As I answer this letter, I am under a strong impression that I wrote you a letter concerning these children after receiving your letter of February 25th, 1944; but I have searched my files and can find no copy of it among them.

The two Edwards children are the children of William Edwards second wife who had attended the R.C. Church in Simpson and in Fort Liard, but joined the Anglican Church in Simpson two years before her death. From information I have received she was buried as a Roman Catholic by the Priest at Fort Liard after her death and I believe was given final rites by him before her death. Their father still claims that they are Protestants, but would only consent to their going to school if they could go to the Providence School, as he is very fond of them and wishes to visit them when it is possible for him to do so. As the only Anglican School in the Territories is at Aklavik 1035 miles distant from his home in Fort Liard, he was bitterly opposed to them going that far away from him, and I may say that I am very much in sympathy with him, as the climate there is much different from that at Fort Liard, being at sea-level, and they seem to be almost out of this world to our local Indians. While the Anglican School was still being conducted at Hay River, there was no objection to the children going there as the distance was not great from their homes, but Providence is so convenient as to distance, that most Indians are glad to send their children there. The same applies to the mother of Thomas Ezea, who resides only 85 miles from the Providence School and can see her child on occasion there. This mother is living with a white man and has been for nine years a few miles above what is called the Head-of-the-Line on the Mackenzie River, but Thomas is a child of a previous liaison and the mother is much opposed to him going further away from home.

I believe that under the circumstances, an exception should be made in cases of this kind, and allow them to go to the nearest
available school, provided their religious beliefs are not interfered with.

The two Edwards children, Vera and Mabel are both of the Anglican religion and Thomas Ezea belongs to the same faith, as his mother is Anglican as are all members of her family.

I should be pleased to hear that this matter has been discussed with the necessary authorities and a reply favorable to their remaining in the School be soon forthcoming.

W.A.M. Truesdell, M.D.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 20, 1945.

Dr. W.A.M. Truesdell, Indian Agent,
Fort Simpson, N.W.T.

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to the Edwards children, and note that their religious affiliation is doubtful. Am I to understand that the children are illegitimate? If so, they would probably be eligible, in view of the information given in your letter regarding their mother. If they are legitimate the father, of course, has the right to direct their education, but, as he is a member of the Church of England, it will not be possible to approve their admission to the Providence Mission Residential School. In this connection, I would refer you to Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act. I note, however, from your letter that he insists on having them attend the Providence School, due to the distance the Aklavik C.E. School is located from his home. Please secure and forward a definite statement from the father to that effect. This should be signed by him, and, when received, the matter will be given further consideration.

With regard to Thomas Ezea, what has been said in connection with the Edwards children applies also in this case, and a signed statement from the boy's mother should also be submitted to us.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, 16th October, 1945.

Dear Sister:

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, James Etetseye may remain in the Providence Mission Residential School for another year.

In reviewing your Form No. I.A. 411 for the June Quarter, it is noted that in applying for discharge of this boy you gave his age as 14 and stated that he had attained the age limit. The age limit for discharge provided by the Indian Act is 16 years of age although the Act gives us the power to keep children for 2 years longer provided the Principal applies for such a permit and the Department considers the reasons given are satisfactory. Possibly you have some understanding to discharge boys when they reach the age of 14. If this is so, I would like to hear from you so I would have the situation in mind for the future.

To Mr. Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir,

Your letter dated October 16th reached destination on November 27th. No mail plane during the Fall period caused the delay in answering your letter.

I am very grateful to you for having granted my request concerning James Etetsaye. In my opinion the boy had to attend school to be helped by the Department, so I wanted to notify you that James was not in attendance in the classroom, but prefers trapping and working with the Oblate Brothers. We seldom have boys of 14 years or over at school. They are taken back by the parents as soon as they can manage a dog or set a trap.

Thanking you for your favorable answer.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am pleased to be able to forward at this time copies of the reports of the school at Fort Providence, for the quarters ending Sept. 30 and Dec. 31st of last year.

The principal of the school has made out a double report for the quarter ending in September, one listing the pupils who remained at school, the other showing the names of those who left for vacation. When the principal learned that you had received neither report, she immediately sent us these, without attempting to have them signed. We regret the long delay, further occasioned by infrequent mail service from Fort Providence.

Fort Simpson, N.W.T. Feb.21. 1946.

Philip Phelan Esq.,
Chief Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

The enclosed Return from the Fort Providence Residential School, is from the Principal, evidently in answer to a request from you for same. It is on the quarterly return form, but is evidently to intimate the number of pupils in attendance at the school at the time it was made out. I did not receive this Form nor the Admission & Discharge Form until this week's mail, and whether it has been delayed at Fort Smith or Edmonton I do not know, as there is no indication on the envelope other than the Fort Providence and Fort Simpson postal stamps. At the same time I received a letter from the Principal, Rev. Sister C. Caron asking me if I had received these Forms, as she had been twice interrogated from Ottawa, re their non-arrival there. This Form would have been of a lot of use to me in my Registration of pupils in attendance at the school through the quarter, but there is no doubt in my mind that the Sister forwarded it when she stated and that it has been lying somewhere in a mislaid mail-bag and has only now been received here.

Yours truly

W.A.M. Truesdell, M.D.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Upon my arrival at Coppermine, I received your letter of July 10th, informing me of your failure to receive the report of the Residential School at Fort Providence for the quarter ending March 31st. I thereupon notified the principal of the school to forward this report at once.

Yesterday I returned to Fort Smith, where I learned that our bursar had in his files a copy of the report for the quarter ending March 31st. This copy I am pleased to enclose herewith, as it will very likely reach you before the copy requested from Providence.

I trust that in the future you will receive these reports regularly, and that there will be no further delay as at present.

Very truly yours,

Bishop J. Trocellier O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie,
Titular Bishop of Adramyttium.

To Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Ottawa

Kind Sir:

Sorry to hear that the March Report of Prov
Res School has not yet reached your office.
I have in due time sent the Quarterly Returns
to the Agent Dr. Treadell asking him to sign & forward immediately.

To avoid such delays in the future, please allow me to send my Reports directly to your office.
I assure you I do all I possibly can to cooperate with you, & alleviate the burden to those who are doing so much for the welfare of our Indian children, and to you Mr. Phelan I owe a big debt of gratitude.

Before closing, I wish to ask you a favor. Kindly send me one of your pictures, size postal card if possible. I will be sure then, that you keep me no grudge and I will be so grateful to you for granting my request.

Sincerely Yours,

Sr. Cecile Baron, S.G.M.,
Principal.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, January 9, 1947.

Dr. W.A.M. Truesdell, Indian Agent,
Fort Simpson, Northwest Territories.

Mrs. Elizabeth Meneza,
Fort Providence, Northwest Territories.

We have recently been requested by the Regional Director of Family Allowances for the Yukon and Northwest Territories to ascertain if Jonas Meneza is out of school for a justifiable reason. We have read your letter of November 13, 1946, in which you set out certain facts concerning this boy and advise that he has been out of school for some time, helping his parents. You are no doubt aware of the regulations of the Northwest Territories Council dealing with the attendance of pupils at residential schools in the Northwest Territories and their discharge therefrom. These regulations were sent to you on file 139-1-10 on March 11, 1935.

The Indian Agent concerned should write to the Department about each individual case of this nature. Then a decision can be reached as to the granting of authority for such discharge. It is not our intention to deprive these boys of proper schooling unless it can be definitely proved that their fathers or relations are going to teach them how to trap.

It is our further intention that only in very exceptional cases will authority ever be granted for boys of 12 and 13 to be excused from school during the trapping season.

You will be interested to know that we are now experimenting with the teaching of trapping in three of our residential schools. If this experiment is a success, then it is our

....... intention
intention to do likewise in other residential schools of the North and to eventually eliminate all necessity of boys under the age of 16 being discharged from our residential schools.

In view of the above information could we please be advised if you consider that this boy is out of school for a justifiable reason and whether we should recommend that family allowances should be made on his behalf.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, July 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing report regarding the death of Elizabeth Menicoche, of the Providence Mission Indian Residential School.

Enclosed is a supply of forms to be used in future.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

J. E. Amyot, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Resolution, N.W.T.
Providence Residential School,
Fort Providence, N.W.T.
October 15, 1947.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:
Enclosed find the Quarterly Returns and Admission Forms for the September Quarter.

You will notice that Pupil No. 0511 is admitted at the age of sixteen (16). This pupil never came to school and insists on remaining.

Another pupil has been sent in lately by the Indian Agent, she also has attained her sixteenth year. Her name will appear on the December Quarterly Return.

Please advise if both pupils may be maintained on report for one year.

Thanking you for your sincere co-operation

I remain yours sincerely,

Sister Mary Mack,
Principal.
Ottawa, November 13, 1947.

Memorandum:

FAMILY ALLOWANCES DIVISION.

Pupils mentioned in letter dated October 29th which is attached, did not return to school in September. This list should also include pupil No. 226 Thomas Villeneuve age thirteen.

These pupils were in attendance during the June Quarter and the school will be allowed grant for July and August.

While this Branch will officially approve their discharge in order that the Principal may drop their names from future Returns, they are discharged because they are absentees.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I am attaching hereto my voucher No. 147 amounting to $174.80, covering the transportation of five Indian children from Fort Simpson to the Fort Providence Indian Residential School.

I know it is not the practice of the Indian Affairs Branch to send children by plane to school, but in this case I deemed it advisable. I was called to see a patient, and on making the call I found the man ill, necessitating his removal to hospital and the family in destitute circumstances, and as this Indian will be unable to do any work for sometime to come, therefore I thought it wise to place the children in school where they would be cared for. Dear Sir:

Re: Mrs. Jerome Bonnet Rouge,
F.A. #10-J-1194,
Fort Simpson, N.W.T.

On August 27th last we wrote to Sister Leduc, Superintendent of St. Mary's Hospital, Fort Simpson, pointing out that we had noted on her July, 1948, report that the child Therese Bonnet Rouge had been discharged on July 10th. We called her attention to the fact that on reviewing this child's file we found that the mother, Mrs. Jerome Bonnet Rouge, had died during the winter of 1944 and 1945, and since the father is also deceased, we are wondering in whose care Therese was placed on her discharge from the hospital.

We have now received a report to the effect that Therese was released during her vacation period to the care of her sister and that she came back to the hospital on August 15th and was once more discharged on September 1, 1948.

Apparently she was to be discharged from the hospital for admission to the Residential School in Fort Providence but Celine Bonnet Rouge, the child's sister who is living with one Alfred Edjus, wanted the child at home to help her and, therefore, took her away from the hospital. According to Sister Leduc, Therese is a sickly child not fit for the life in the bush and she states "as Therese is of school age, 12 years old, the Agent should be notified and the girl sent back to school".

The above information is sent to you for whatever action you deem necessary.

Yours very truly,

W. F. Hendershot,
Regional Director,

October 14, 1948.

Dear Sister Mack:

We have reviewed the enclosed Return and we feel that you are not fully conversant with the manner in which Quarterly Returns should be prepared. As a result, we feel that you are not requesting as much grant in many cases as you are entitled to receive.

I am, therefore, enclosing a copy of our circular dated December 29, 1944 regarding the preparation of Quarterly Returns and I would also refer you to the instructions contained on the back page of the Quarterly Return form. May I take as an instance the case of Patrice Nadli No. 248, who apparently was in school during the June Quarter until it closed for the summer holidays. From the information we have, the school closed for holidays about the 24th of June and as you are only entitled to take two months' holidays, it is presumed that it re-opened about August 24th. Therefore, pupils who are in the school at the time the school closes for summer holidays are entitled to receive sixty-two days holiday grant on the September Quarterly Return. From the information contained on the Return, it would appear that this boy returned four days late, consequently, you are entitled to grant for him for the following period:

62 days holiday grant minus six days taken in June Quarter - 56 holiday grant and in addition 26 days during which it is presumed that he was in school during the September Quarter, therefore a total of 82 days instead of the 17 which you requested.
It is important as far as the school is concerned to request the correct number of days under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during the Quarter" as the grant is paid on the aggregate number of these days.

From the circular and the information given above, I feel certain that you will be able to revise the Return. I might add that in cases like No. 277 Henry Simba where you mention "At home may Return" if this pupil was in the school when it closed for the summer holidays, you are entitled to fifty-six days on the September Quarterly Return.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

AIR MAIL

July 25th, 1949.

Rev. Sister Mary Mack,
Principal,
Providence Mission Res. School,
Fort Providence, N.W.T.

Reverend and Dear Sister:

We are sending back the June Quarter Return for the Providence Mission Residential School, as we cannot understand why you have only asked 86 days grant in the case of several of the children, but do not give any reason for such action under the column headed "Remarks".

As you are aware, the Department allows 92 days for holidays, and in any case where a school closes before the end of June, the management ask for the full grant for the quarter, due to the fact that it has always been understood that the children return to school 4 or 5 days before September 1st.

Please review the return and if you consider it advisable to make any changes in the case of those for whom you have asked only 86 days, you should do so. If not, you should explain under the column headed "Remarks" why you ask 86 days.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,

Sacred Heart School,
Fort Providence, N.W.T.
September 28, 1950.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch. Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

On the last June Report sent from this School, the former Principal, Sister Mary Mack has discharged two pupils having come to Age Limit of Residential Schools: Alice Bewule and Corinne Bonnet Rouge.

I confidentially take the liberty to ask a permit of extension in School for these two girls who really have no homes at present and who wish to continue their work in school.

The same favor would be asked for Jane Tale who was sixteen in June but who came back after holidays wishing to learn some more in School and Home Economics.

Hoping for a favorable reply,

I remain,

Respectfully yours,

Sister Elizabeth Kristoff
Principal.
October 4, 1950.

Rev. Sister Elizabeth Kristoff,
Principal,
Providence Mission Residential School,
Fort Providence, N.W.T.

Reverend and Dear Sister:

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, the Department approves the undermentioned children remaining in the Providence Mission Residential School until the end of June, 1951.

Alice Bewule
Corinne Bonnet Rouge
Jane Tale

If you desire to keep any or all of the above girls after the date mentioned above, further application should be made to this office early in July of 1951.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Mr. D.M. MacKay, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Joe Zaul an Indian of Fort Norman is seeking information regarding his right to place his three children to the Residential School at Fort Providence, while the local Indian Agent is opposing in order to keep the said children at the Norman Indian Day School.

Father Beauregard, on behalf of Joe Zaul, asked me advise on the case and requested that information be sought near the proper authorities.

I presume that the motives of Joe Zaul to place his children to The R.C. Residential school at Fort Providence is either one of conscience or of the difficulty of boarding his children in town during the school year.

In any case, since the section (118) of the new Indian Act provides that the Minister may designate such school to which every Indian child shall attend, I deem advisable to submit to you Joe Zaul's request.

You may recall that a similar case has been submitted to the Deputy Commissioner some years ago when a parent of Catholic Faith refused to place his children in a neutral school for reasons of conscience and was not compelled to comply with the wishes of the local authorities that the said child be placed to the local neutral school. I am referring to the Tuktuayuktuk Territorial School.

Apparently, Joe Zaul wants to send his 3 children to the Residential School at Fort Providence on the Mission's Boat which is due back at Fort Norman from Aklavit about the 10th of this month and will not make a second trip down there. Therefore, I beg of you to give this case your earliest attention and, if at all possible, inform by telegram Joe Zaul of your decision or of the Minister's decision as to whether or not his children are authorized to attend the Residential School at Fort Providence during the coming school year.

I fully realize, dear Mr. MacKay, the implications of my action, since the authority of one of your Agent is concerned. However, you will agree that your Department is entitled to all information for its own interest as well as for the interest of the Indians.

I may add that having incidentally met here today Mr. J.A. Simons, M.P., I sought his opinion with regard to the case of Joe Zaul and was advised by him to refer the matter to yourself. I feel then that you will welcome this opportunity to clarify the application of one section of the new Act regarding Indians.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Mission came to this office and on July 22, 1951, the Mission boat picked up this child Walter Blondin taking him to the Providence Residential School. The attached Application being handed to me for signature the following day.

The father of the child Walter, Joseph Blondin, is presently employed as a pilot with the Northern Transportation Company, the mother and the remainder of the family are living in the Settlement. As you are aware we operate the Fort Norman Indian Day school throughout the summer months, in an effort to give education to children such as this child Walter. I would venture to say that the Blondin family will be residing within the Fort at least seven months out of the year, I therefore do not agree that the Department should be charged for the keep of this child at a Residential school.

I have received information that the R.C. Mission have entered Metis children in the Residential school, for the sum of $3.00 each per month plus the Family Allowances. I would suggest that

May I please have your decision in this matter. If we are to allow the Indians to send children to and from Residential schools, using that institution as a Hotel for their convenience, there is little hope that our day schools will succeed.

It has always been our practise to encourage all children, who are orphans or even of a family where one of the parents are deceased, to go to residential school. I feel safe in saying that there are sufficient number of children in the Agency under this category to more than fill all residential schools.

Re: Walter Blondin

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In reply to your letter of the 15th inst. regarding attendance of Walter Blondin at the Fort Providence Indian Residential School, I would say that in my opinion, there is sufficient reason for his presence there.

From my personal conviction, as well as that of all our missionaries, and without blaming altogether the report of Mr. Hunter, I believe I am right in saying that the Indian Act provides Boarding or Day schools for Indian children, without specifying to which of the two kinds of schools a particular child is obliged to go. If I remember well, I have never noticed, in reading the Indian Act, that Boarding Schools are to be provided only for orphans and abandoned children.

It appears to me that Indian parents enjoy the privilege guaranteed them by their Treaty, of sending their children to the school of their choice, whether it be a Boarding School or a Day School.

There is no doubt that a residential school is better equipped in the long run, than a day school, to supervise the instruction of children in general, and more particularly in the case of Indian children. These children have a more balanced diet, are taught to develop habits of cleanliness; they attend classes with greater regularity; they receive a general and practical education in such things as cooking, sewing, laundry work, manual occupations etc., beside the ordinary classroom studies.

How then could we blame Indian parents if they choose a residential school for their children? Should we not encourage them in their choice?

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6476, file 918-10, part 4)
As regards Mr. Hunter's main objection, the expenses involved, I am under the impression that the maintenance of a day school is costing the Government more per capita and per day of attendance of pupils, than keeping them in a boarding school, where the cost is presently calculated at less than a dollar per day per pupil.

It would therefore not seem to be the presence of the parents in the Fort for a considerable portion of the year, which should determine the choice of the school, but it ought to be rather the choice of the parents which determines it. Although the right to choose is not specified as such in the Indian Act, it is likewise not denied to them either, but is more or less upheld by the Act, in principle.

The fact is that some parents do not yet realize the benefits of sending their children to a residential school. They keep them in the Fort with them, either to profit by the family allowance or under pretence of sending them to school, and thus carry on a rather precarious existence, being frequently compelled to ask for Government support. This would be avoided if the parents were in the bush hunting or trapping.

With all these reasons in mind, Father Beauregard took advantage of the passage of the mission boat on its way to Port Providence, to send Walter Blondin to the residential school there, having in view rather the interest of the child, rather than to counteract any policy of the Department.

I trust that these reasons will convey to you the expression of my position in this instance, and remain,

very truly yours,

Bishop J. Trocellier O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of Mackenzie,
Titular Bishop of Adramyttium.

Attached herewith please find the quarterly school returns for both the Providence and the Ft. Resolution R.C. Mission Residential Schools.

Please note that there are some application for Admission forms for children from the Ft. Norman Agency. These children could have attended the Day School at Ft. Norman and in fact, one by the name of Walter Blondin had attended for two years at that point and could very well have continued according to a letter I have received from Mr. Hunter. He has written you on this score and I cannot approve the application, but as the child is on my quarterly return I do not approve of his tuition unless you wish him to be included.

We have a number of day schools in this country and all the teachers are R.C. where the majority of the children are of this faith and in accordance with the Indian Act. Where these are provided and the family can look after the children I do not see any reason why we should pay for them at Residential school. We have many children who are orphans or whose fathers or mothers are in hospital and these should be the ones taken into the Mission schools, also children whose homes are back in the bush and school attendance not possible.

I have found that the Missions are very reluctant to let the school children go home for the summer holidays for fear they will not come back and if they do they may have to pay for the transportation. This condition has made it difficult to get some of the Indians to send their children back to school once they get them home because they say the Mission never sends them
back for the summer. This is partly true due to our difficulties in transportation with its high cost. I was able to take a number of children home this summer with my boat but it is not a passenger boat and is not always available. Not to send the children home is bad both for the children and the parent. If when the children do not return to school and we demand that they go back to school someone has to pay the transportation and I wish to know whether it is authorized to transport children to and from Residential school at Government expense. It is realized that we spend a great deal on the Indian but where they live off the land they, as a rule, have little or no money and if we are to make the younger Indians better citizens and better equipped to look after themselves then I feel that we should be able to transport school children to and from school where they live in isolated points. In this respect I refer to Snowdrift and Ft Rae in particular as the other settlements either have the schools or can get there without much trouble.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

File 918-10 (F6)

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In reply to your letter of the 2nd inst. regarding the recruiting of Indian residential school pupils in the North, I feel that in cases where the missions are reluctant to let the children return home for summer holidays, there is usually a very good reason for such reluctance. A certain number of these children are orphans, or have no one interested enough in them, especially the younger ones who are too small to help with household work. Others I have seen waiting more than half the summer for parents or relatives who promised to come for them to take them on vacation, and then showed up about the time school was beginning in September. On more than just a few occasions, the Indians requested the return home of their children for the summer, and expected the missions to pay the transportation by plane, with no intention of refunding such expenses, even after they had more or less promised to do so.

I know very well the remarks of the Indians who are inclined to blame the missions for not sending the children home for the summer, and I would be very much gratified to see the foregoing reasons considered by Mr. Kirkby and the Department, alongside the complaints of the Indians.

We realize very well, since it occurs every summer, that many Indian parents will not avail themselves of the opportunity of sending back to school children who have already spent several weeks at home. They are advised well beforehand when the Mission Boat is due on its last return trip, and if the children (and even the parents) can be found at all when the boat arrives, they insist that the children are not ready, or they are sick, or they will bring them later on themselves, or they are needed at home this year, or simply that they are not returning to school. Our boat has frequently been retarded for hours, waiting for children who were certainly returning to school; it has even made special trips which proved useless, in order to call for children whose parents had "changed their minds" about sending them.

Mr. I.F. Kirkby,

Yellowknife, N.W.T.,

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the Providence Mission Indian Residential School, the Principal has claimed 61 days for pupil #332 and has shown that this pupil was admitted to the school on April 1, 1952. In view of the prescribed number of days in the quarter the school was entitled to 91 days grant for this pupil, however, as the Principal claimed 61 days it is presumed that the pupil was either admitted later than April 1 or was truant during the quarter.

As it is not possible to pay the per capita grant for the quarter without information on this pupil and as we are not anxious to withhold payment until full information is obtained we are disallowing per capita grant for this pupil on the June return and are asking the Treasury Office to pay the balance.

Please instruct the Principal that she may claim this grant on the September Quarterly Return but it will be necessary for her to indicate in the Remarks Column the reason for claiming 61 days for the June Quarter and the dates the pupil was absent during the quarter.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Providence Mission Indian Residential School, as we have not received the necessary applications for admission for pupils # 0359 Bella Sambelle, # 0360 Denise Moses, # 0361 Adeline Nahany and # 0362 Phoebe R. Nahany, their admission to the Providence Mission school has not been approved, consequently we are disallowing the per capita grant claimed for them.

It would be appreciated if you would secure these applications and forward them to this office for consideration. When the admissions are approved the Principal may claim retroactive grant for the children on the December Quarterly Return. For your information the Principal neglected to include # 0359 on Form I.A. 411. It will be necessary for him to do so on the December Return.

It is noted that in many cases, the pupils returned to school later than September 1, however, the Principal has neglected to indicate in the Remarks Column the exact dates these pupils returned to school. We will pay the per capita grant payment on the Return as presented, however, in future it will be necessary to return the document to the Principal to indicate the dates the children returned or were truant during the quarter.
The Principal has claimed 39 days grant for pupil # 0290. As this pupil was in residence during June 1952, the school is entitled to the per capita grant for July and August which is a total of 62 days, consequently we are increasing the grant to 62 days for this pupil.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

The following wireless message has been received from Dr. E.J. Baker, Medical Health Officer at Fort Simpson.

"Louis Betsidea refuses send Camilla and Marie Therese to Providence stop can I send them as they need further nursing care and we need the hospital beds."

Louis Betsidea and his five children have all been confined to Fort Simpson hospital since July of last year. The mother is deceased. The two children referred to are now ready for discharge but require daily rest periods. Marie Therese is 12, and Camilla is 8 years of age. Doctor Baker proposes to send them to the Residential School at Fort Providence where they would receive nursing care, as he requires the hospital beds, but the father refuses to let them go. The family is from Fort Franklin, and there is no one there who is willing to care for the children.

As Mr. Betsidea is confined to hospital and unable to care for his family, it would appear that he is hardly in a position to refuse, and I would appreciate your advice as to whether or not they may be sent to Fort Providence school without his permission. The cost of maintenance in the hospital amounts to $4.50 per day. They are Roman Catholics, so there is no reason why they should not be admitted to the Providence School.

If you approve their admittance, would you please advise by wireless message, in order that I may make the necessary arrangements. The cost of transportation would amount to $38.00.

A.V. Cottrell, Superintendent,
Fort Norman, Indian Agency.

We are in receipt of the following wireless message from Rev. Father V. Phillipe of Fort Franklin.

"Ferdinand and Joe Kenny asking for their boys John and George, about five years old, to go to school stop have contacted Mission Fort Smith regarding new kindergarten orphanage this their reply quote arrange with Agent for their admission and transportation to here".

The children referred to by Father Phillipe are John Ferdinand, born May 28, 1948, and George Kenny born April 7, 1950. The fathers of these children are both widowers and maintain that they are unable to care for the children and do their hunting and trapping.

I have information that Mr. Kenny expects to remarry in the near future and I cannot see the need of sending his child to Fort Smith. I am aware also that the child has been maintained by another family since shortly after birth, so it is not a question of having him cared for.

The child John Ferdinand is five years of age, and it would appear that the best solution would be to arrange for his admission to a Residential School, rather than a kindergarten, as his father is actually finding difficulty maintaining him. If you approve, we
will endeavor to have him admitted to the Residential School at Fort Providence. His transportation would amount to approximately $120.00.

It is not understood why these men have delayed so long in requesting that their children be sent to school. If the request had been received a month earlier they could have been sent to Fort Smith with the R.C. Mission boat at no cost to us. To have them sent to Fort Smith by air would be very costly and it is not considered that the expense would be justified.

A.V. Cottrell, Superintendent,
Fort Norman Indian Agency.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that in accordance with your instructions I met Mr. Scott, Department of Indian Affairs, at his office on the 27th instant. At his request I am submitting the following information, and would respectfully request that same be forwarded to him.

At present time Eskimo children of school age are sent to the Church of England Mission boarding school at Hay River for periods of four to five years. Owing to the great distance, the parents cannot see their children during that period, and are generally adverse to sending their children to the school. Last summer the Eskimo of the Mackenzie delta offered to build a school at Aklavik and pay the salary of a teacher if only the school could be located at that point or on the coast. I would estimate that there are about seventy-five hundred children of school age among the Western Eskimos. The Church of England Mission are building a hospital at Aklavik this next year, and Doctor Doyle will be stationed there.

The Mission, I understand, are anxious to build a school for the Eskimo exclusively, but are faced with the fact that whereas at Hay River potatoes and other vegetables can be grown in sufficient quantities to feed all the children the year round and with fish form the main articles of food, it would not be possible to raise any vegetables at Aklavik. Therefore, all articles of food would have to be purchased and shipped into the country. A large amount of fish can be supplied at Aklavik, and the coast. The present government allowance to the Mission of $200.00 per child per year in residence would not, therefore, be sufficient under the circumstances, and I would suggest that it be doubled, with a view to encouraging the Mission in erecting a school.

The Eskimo are most anxious to send their children to school. It has been noticed that some Eskimo children on return from Hay River school have adopted some of the worst traits of the Indians.
Again an Eskimo child returns after four or five years at Hay River school, cannot speak the Eskimo language, is unused and dislikes the Eskimo food and mode of living; cannot hunt or trap, and is in fact a stranger to the parents and the country.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

The Executive Committee of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada has instructed me to place before you a formal and official statement in relation to the question of the educational facilities required for the Indian and Eskimo population of the North West Territories.

The Church of England sent its first missionary to the Takudh Indians of the Peel River in the year 1861, and has been in continuous missionary occupation of that region, therefore, for over 60 years.

The Rev.I.O.Stringer, now Anglican Bishop of the Yukon, founded the Herschel Island and Mackenzie River Delta Mission to the Eskimo in the year 1894. This mission has also been continuously carried on by the Church of England.

In the year 1915 the Rev.H.Girling, and his associates, took up their residence at Bernard Harbour, Coronation Gulf, and founded our existing mission to the Eskimo of those regions.

With the possible exception of a few employees of the trading companies there are to be found, along the Peel River and northwards, we believe, no adherents or members of any religious body other than the Church of England. Until a few months ago the most northerly
mission station of the Roman Catholic Church was at Arctic Red River. The authorities of the latter body, we are informed, have recently occupied the new trading centre of Aklavik in the Mackenzie River Delta; and, if rumour is to be credited, have already submitted the proposal, or suggestion, to your Department that an Indian Residential School be established at Aklavik under their auspices.

Our Executive Committee, and also our Indian and Eskimo Commission, has given very careful consideration to the entire question under discussion with particular reference to the fact that about 85% of the pupilage of the existing Church of England Indian Residential School at Hay River, Great Slave Lake, is brought from Fort MacPherson on the Peel River and the surrounding regions of the Mackenzie River Delta. The Committee also has in mind the fact that, while the Church of England community among the Indians of the region of Great Slave Lake is comparatively small, the whole of the Christian Indians and Eskimos, northwards of the Roman Catholic Station at Arctic Red River, are members of the Church of England. The members of our Executive Committee, and of our Indian and Eskimo Commission, are unanimously of the conviction, therefore, that immediate steps should be taken with a view to securing proper educational advantages for our people and for the non-Christian Indians or Eskimos of the region of the Mackenzie River Delta and the Arctic Coast of the North West Territories.

The Executive bodies mentioned have also given careful consideration to the question as to whether such educational advantages would be best provided through the establishment of a new Church of England residential school at Aklavik or some other suitable point in the Delta, or by the transfer to such suitable point of our existing institution at Hay River, Great Slave Lake. The Executive Committee, and the Indian and Eskimo Commission came unanimously to the decision that, providing satisfactory ways and means are provided for the maintenance of such an institution at
such distant and isolated point can be satisfactorily worked out, our interests will be best served by the transfer of the existing Hay River institution.

The Executive Committee instructed me to take up these questions further with you, with a view to an investigation of the conditions under which such an institution, if established in the Delta, must be administered and maintained; and with the object of arriving at a basis of agreement, in connection with these matters, as between your Department and the Missionary Society in the hope that, in due course, you will see your way clear to approve the proposed transfer of the Hay River institution and to provide the capital and other sums connected with the carrying out of the plan.

I shall hope to have an opportunity of discussing these matters personally with you on the occasion of my next visit to Ottawa.

A similar situation to that described above exists on the East shore of James and Hudson's Bay. The Church of England first occupied these regions in the decade of 1850-60 and have been in continued missionary occupation since that time. One of our chief stations at Fort George has recently been occupied by Roman Catholic missionaries. We understand, however, that the Anglican Bishop of Moosonee has lodged a formal petition with your Department for an Indian Residential School to be located at Fort George, or other suitable point in the region, to be administered by the Church of England. The Executive Committee M.S.C.C. endorses this application of the Bishop of Moosonee and considers the fact of its lodgement with your Department as a sufficient interim safeguard of our interests in the regions affected, viz—the East coast of James and Hudson's Bay.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

General Secretary.

Dear Mr Scott:

Some two years ago I had the pleasure of meeting you and discussing with you the need of a school for the Eskimo children in the vicinity of Aklavik, MacKenzie River delta and Herschel Island. In July of this year I was transferred here after five years residence at Herschel Island during which period I became thoroughly acquainted with the Eskimos on the coast as far east as Tree River and have always been keenly interested in their welfare. As I pointed out to you at the time of our last interview, the parents are reluctant to allow their children to go to the Mission school at Hay River owing to the great distance and the period, usually three to five years, the child is retained at the school. Needless to say that the parents cannot visit their children during this period owing to the distance and it is usual that they demand their children back after the first year or two which of course is not in the best interests of the child. I neglected to mention that all Eskimos of the MacKenzie delta and coast are confirmed members of the Church of England.

I am informed that at last efforts are being made to build a school for Eskimos only, either in the delta or on the coast since it is generally agreed that the Indians and Eskimos should be kept in separate schools. Aklavik, in the delta, is the dividing line between Indians and Eskimos, in fact both live and trade there and I believe some people are in favor of building the school at this point rather than on the coast; however, this is not the natural hunting ground of the Eskimos as it is heavily timbered and some ninety miles from the coast. Fishing is poor at Aklavik while the seal, white whale and fish are abundant on the coast only and are the natural food of the Eskimos. Aklavik is too near the hunting grounds and settlements of the Indians at Hay River and Macpherson who, for the same reason as the Eskimos, are reluctant to send their children long distance to Hay River school. On the other hand the Indians will not go on the coast nor can they live on the Eskimo food of seal or whale. As I said before fishing is poor at Aklavik and caribou never come within striking distance.

In my opinion Herschel Island is the only place for a school, 200 miles from Aklavik. Here is the largest Eskimo permanent settlement on the coast or interior, namely about
ten families; all the staple foods of the Eskimo are obtained here, seal are plentiful, also salt water fish such as herring, salmon and white fish; white whale and bowhead whales are hunted here in summer; caribou are very plentiful on the mainland less than one day's travel at any time of the year, white foxes and polar bear are usually as plentiful here as anywhere on the coast; in short the Eskimo children would be 'at home' in a school at Herschel Isl., and the parents would be able to visit them once a year about August.

Shingle Point might be mentioned as a suitable place for the school since it is just at the mouth of the Mackenzie River on the coast, however there is this disadvantage about Shingle Point in that it is so close to the river that the water is partly fresh and therefore no seals or big whales come near there. The fishing is very good and caribou are never far off but not as good as at Herschel Isl., 63 miles to the westward. There is no permanent settlement of Eskimo at Shingle Point as at Herschel, also in past few years there have been four epidemics of typhoid fever which are believed to originate at Shingle Point since the water supply is bad at that point.

I have seen many sad cases of Eskimo children returning to their parents after three and five years at the Hay River school. They could not eat the native food; could not speak enough Eskimo to understand their own parents and knew nothing of making the Eskimo boots, clothing, working skins, in fact anything that would be useful in their everyday life among their own people. In consequence they were looked upon by their own parents and others as useless and in several instances parents who had attended Hay River school in their youth, refused to send their own children to the school in view of their own experiences. That is more Eskimo children seem to have adopted the worst traits of the Indian while at Hay River school.

I have on several occasions lately officially reported the manner in which the Eskimo are exploited by traders, particularly in Coronation Gulf, and I hope these reports have been placed before you. I have the greatest admiration for the Eskimo and hope to get back to the Arctic first opportunity. If there is any information you should want concerning these people and the country, I would be only too glad to give it to you to the best of my ability, in the meantime I hope that what I have said concerning the school may be of some use to you should the matter come to your attention.

Yours truly,

S. Wood

Dear Mr. Scott:

Bishop Lucas having resigned from the Diocese of Mackenzie River, the Archbishop of Rupert Island commissioned me to visit the same this year, to take note of conditions, as well as to administer it.

There are one or two observations that may affect your department which I take the liberty of making.

The Roman Catholic Church has erected a large building at Aklavik, designed probably for a boarding school, and have taken some 18 or more children from Good Hope and Red River to train. This is all to the good, but their main object seems to be to secure Eskimo children from Aklavik and the Delta, where they have not one adherent of their church.

Their representative, Mr. Gui, is here now, professedly to examine the school situation for the Government, and may report that the school facilities are already adequate. From his point of view they may be, but not from the point of view of the natives.

I have in my possession two largely signed petitions, one by the Eskimos and one by the Indians of McPherson, asking for schools where their children may be trained, free from the Roman influence. These petitions will come to you in due course, through the proper channel.

There were at McPherson this summer 321 Indians, of whom at least 60 were of school age, 6 to 15, and the petition contains names of parents of 160 below the age of 16, none of whom can on any account be induced to attend the Roman Catholic School at Aklavik.

They are exceedingly anxious to have a school at their own place, and from the above, you will see that there is sufficient material available, both for the present, and as to the future, the births at McPherson during the past 30 months number 52, of whom only 3 have died during that time.

This, Mr. Scott, is for your information in case any representations are made from the other side. You know, of course, that they have no standing with the people either at McPherson or in the Delta of the McKenzie River.

Sincerely yours,

Extract of Commissary's Report, August, 1926

"I had two long conferences with the Indians at both Akivik and McPherson, which resulted in a petition to the Indian Dept. to establish a Residential school in the North for Indian children, as Hay River is too far to send their children. It may be well to point out that the one mission of McPherson alone has supplied perhaps 70% of all the children entering the Hay River School for the past twenty years. The parents complain of the great distance, and of their inability to see their children in times of sickness.

"If it were possible to establish a school here (at McPherson) of the capacity of the Hay River School, there are sufficient children on hand at this moment, and barring epidemics, a practical certainty that there will be for years to come, children that would be gladly given, to fill it to capacity.

"The fish here are not so good as at Hay River, but would yield a good deal. Also there would be no potato crop, but these are handicaps to be overcome.

"An attached list shows the children who at present make this their summer gathering place. This summer there were some 350 Indians visited here. It has the further advantage of an old established mission, with practically new residence and church, and over fifty Indian residences. Attached photo shows some of them."

Dear Dr. McGill:

Pursuant to our usual custom, I submit my understanding of the agreement reached at our interview held on Saturday morning the 7th inst.

Our interview concerned in the main the situation brought about through the erection by this Society, at Aklavik N.W.T., of a residential school building, designed to accommodate the indian children from the lower Mackenzie Valley provided for in the past by the Indian Residential School at Hay River and also the eskimo children provided for by the existing Residential School at Shingle Point.

We agreed:

1. That the opening of the new school at Aklavik with the receipt of per capita grants for the indian children in question; should not involve the abandonment of residential school provision for the anglican indian children resident in the Hay River area.

2. That this provision for the Hay River area should take the form of an institution which I described as a "Family Indian Residential School;" that is a small school of probably not more than fifteen or twenty pupils, the staff for which would probably consist of the Principal (probably a married man) who would be the teacher, one supervisor, one kitchen matron; the Department continuing to provide the usual per capita grants in aid.

N.B. Since all the lands and buildings in question are owned by this Society; we would be responsible for the cost of any reconstruction required.

3. That you would take into sympathetic consideration
The Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs....2

the request for a small grant, say $2,000.00, toward
the equipment of the new Residential School at Aklavik.

4. That the hospital at Hay River will be continued as at
present.

We expect, I may add, to have the Aklavik School ready next
Autumn for the reception of the eskimo children from Shingle Point,
together with new indian pupils from the lower Mackenzie. We think
it best that the senior indian pupils now at Hay River should complete
their education there; and the others be transferred to Aklavik by
the last boat of the summer of 1937.

If there are any points in which your understanding of the results
of our interview differs from mine as set out above; please let me know.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, setting forth your understanding of an interview with myself on the 7th instant, regarding the situation brought about through the erection, by your Society, of a residential school at Aklavik, North West Territories, to accommodate the Indian and Eskimo children from the lower Mackenzie Valley.

As agreed in my letter to you of May 14th, 1935, grant is being provided for a total of 50 pupils at Hay River, as from April first, 1937. In the event of the residential school at Hay River being continued for approximately 15 children from that neighbourhood, the Indian pupilage that can be provided for at the new school at Aklavik will be 35 children, or, the total number for which grant can be provided at both schools is 50 pupils. Payment of the grant to Aklavik could begin as from the time the pupils now at Hay River have been transferred to that school.

The Department would favourably consider continuing the residential school at Hay River for the benefit of the Anglican Indian children in that neighbourhood and provide grant for approximately 15 pupils - it being understood, however, as all the buildings in question at this point are owned by your Society, that the Society will be responsible for the entire cost of any reconstruction or repairs.

Dear Sir:

Having recently returned from a visit to Aklavik, N.W.T., I am able to inform you that the new school building built by our Church at this centre to combine the activities of the Eskimo School at Shingle Point, and some of the activities of our Hay River School, will be ready for occupation in August. Miss Helena Sowden, the Head Matron of our Hay River School, is now on her way to Aklavik to fill the same position there, and she will take a few girl pupils with her. The other lady agents will take with them the other pupils who are to be transferred this year by the next boat. It is important that class-room registers and forms for quarterly and yearly returns be sent forward at once, and I will be obliged if you will either send these to me, or direct to the Principal, the Rev. H.S. Shepherd, B.A.

I enclose herewith a small photo of the school building itself, and three snaps of supplies and building material landed on the river bank about 400 yards away by the path which has to be followed. The workmanship throughout impressed me as being excellent, and I was more than surprised at the skill of the Loucheaux Indian carpenters who had been trained by the master-builders, Messrs. Somers and Quartermain, and who had greatly assisted in the erection of this spacious and suitable building. The building has easily a capacity of 150 pupils, but instructions were given by me to the Principal not to enroll more than 100 at the time of opening.
An enrolment of fully 150 could easily be effected at once, but I felt it prudent to begin with the lower number, and I trust this arrangement may be agreeable to your Department, and also to the Department of the N.W.T., to whom I am sending a copy of this letter for their information. Just now I am unable to say exactly how many of the pupils will be Indians and how many Eskimo, but am of the opinion the Indians will number between 60 and 70 and the Eskimo between 40 and 30 during the first year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Canon Gould:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, setting forth your understanding of an interview with myself on the 7th instant, regarding the situation brought about through the erection, by your Society, of a residential school at Aklavik, North West Territories, to accommodate the Indian and Eskimo children from the lower Mackenzie Valley.

As agreed in my letter to you of May 14th, 1935, grant is being provided for a total of 50 pupils at Hay River, as from April first, 1937. In the event of the residential school at Hay River being continued for approximately 15 children from that neighbourhood, the Indian pupilage that can be provided for at the new school at Aklavik will be 35 children, or, the total number for which grant can be provided at both schools is 50 pupils. Payment of the grant to Aklavik could begin as from the time the pupils now at Hay River have been transferred to that school.

The Department would favourably consider continuing the residential school at Hay River for the benefit of the Anglican Indian children in that neighbourhood and provide grant for approximately 15 pupils - it being understood, however, as all the buildings in question at this point are owned by your Society, that the Society will be responsible for the entire cost of any reconstruction or repairs that may in future be required.

Regarding the request that a grant of $2,000.00 be provided towards the equipment of the new residential school at Aklavik, I would say, while no funds have been specially provided in our Appropriation for the coming fiscal year for this purpose, it will, no doubt, be found possible to grant some assistance towards the cost of furnishing the building.

The Department agrees that the senior Indian pupils from the lower Mackenzie Valley, now at the Hay River School, remain and complete their education and that the others from that district be transferred to the new school at Aklavik during the summer of 1937.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.D., D.C.L.,

Dear Sir:

I am deeply obliged to you for your prompt reply on the 25th ultimo No. 141-1-1 to my letter of July 25th re class-room registers, forms, etc., and the authorized pupilage for our new school at Aklavik.

With regard to the authorized pupilage for this school I pointed out in my letter of July 25th, that the building has easily a capacity of 150, and that I had given instructions to the Principal not to enroll more than 100 at the time of opening. During my visit to Aklavik last month I spoke to Dr. Urquhart about the admission of pupils, and informed him that our Society did not contemplate admitting this fall a larger number of pupils than they specified, and I received the impression that he considered this arrangement reasonable, and would support it.

I was surprised therefore, to learn from a telegram just received from the Reverend Principal Shepherd who is in charge of our Aklavik School, that the Doctor has recommended "grants for 75 only". Principal Shepherd asks in his telegram if our Commission can possibly arrange for the children who are expected from the Hay River School to remain there another year. This request is based on the fact that there are a number of children living at Aklavik whose parents desire them to be admitted at once. I have already sent a short Lettergram to Principal Shepherd informing him that as food and clothing supplies have already been shipped to Aklavik for the children who were being transferred from Hay River, these children cannot remain there, but will be allowed to proceed to their homes at Ft. McPherson, and remain there until accommodation is available for them on a per capita grant-earning basis. As I can well believe that this arrangement may prove disappointing to the children from the Hay River School, as well as to their parents, I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if your Department and the
Department of the North West Territories can authorize for the first year's operations at Aklavik, a minimum pupilage of 80. So small a pupilage will not provide sufficient revenue to operate the school, as we have already appointed a full staff, and the agents who have not yet reached the school, are now on their way. You will know as well as I that problems of the kind in question are inevitable in connection with the opening up of a new unit of instruction such as the one at Aklavik.

The difficulties in the way of solving such problems are accentuated by the remoteness of the location from your Department in Ottawa, and our Commission in Winnipeg. The action, however, taken by our Society in providing the building, and the suggestion I have made that only 80 instead of 100 be admitted the first year, must surely convince you of the sincerity and willingness on our part to help in the solution of these problems, and I very earnestly hope that between your Department and the Department of the North West Territories, grants for a minimum pupilage of 80 pupils will be authorized for the first year of the Aklavik's School's operations.

As the steamer which is to take the pupils from Hay River to Aklavik is now due to leave Fort Smith in the N.W.T., and to reach Hay River, if it adheres to its schedule, in less than a week, it will be appreciated if you can let me have your reply to this letter in time for me to communicate with the Principal of our Hay River School before the children embark. It is not our intention to maintain at the Hay River School during the coming year more than fifteen pupils, but if authority is given for the enrolment of 80 children at the Aklavik School, some of those who would otherwise have to stay at home for a year, could continue on the boat and be received into the Aklavik School.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

During my visit to Aklavik in July of this year I discussed with Dr. Urquhart of your Department, with Major Irvine, Superintendent of the R.C.M.P. in the N.W.T., and with various others, the question of having one central lighting system for the whole of the Aklavik settlement, and found that a strongly unanimous opinion prevailed that it was highly desirable to have such a system of lighting installed if any possible arrangement could be found for this to be done. At the present time some privately owned lighting systems are in use, but the settlement is so small and compact that the noise of the motors required to operate these was causing a good deal of interference with radio reception. As the whole settlement does not extend over an area of approximately one quarter of a square mile, there can be no doubt about the advantages which this central lighting system would provide.

The interest of our Society in the matter centres chiefly around the fact that an electric lighting system will be required for the new Indian and Eskimo Residential School which we have just built there. The School building has been completed and will be in operation during the coming winter, but the lamps which will be used this winter should be superseded by a better lighting system before another winter sets in.

From the interview I had with the parties mentioned, I received the impression that a central lighting system could best be handled by the Royal Canadian Corps Signals, and I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if there is any possibility of such an arrangement being made. Speaking for our Society I may say that we would much prefer to secure
in that way the lighting required in our School, than through
the installation of our own lighting plant. While the Church
of England Hospital which is now being re-built at Aklavik
will not be administered by our Society, Bishop Fleming
informed me that he would prefer to have that institution
and all the buildings in his Aklavik Mission lighted from a
central lighting plant than from a separate plant which he
would have to install for the purpose. As the Hudson's Bay
Co., the Northern Trading Co., the Roman Catholic Mission,
in addition to other residents in the settlement, would
probably contract for lighting from a central lighting
system, I have every reason to believe that a central
lighting system of the kind I have mentioned could be
operated without cost to your Department, apart from the
initial cost of installation.

As our Society must take steps to provide our School
with a fully modern lighting system next year, I shall be
glad to know whether the central lighting system of the
type I have suggested for the whole settlement can be pro-
vided or not.

Your obedient servant,

TBRW/KH
