Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on the activities of the Church of England at Aklavik:

A School has just been completed there that will accommodate probably 150 children. They also had a new Principal's house and I was informed the old Church was to be torn down and rebuilt on a larger plan. They were also working on a new hospital. As only the frame of this was up I can say very little about this building, but I was very well pleased with the arrangement of the school, and must say it was very well laid out and it will certainly meet the requirements.

What surprised me most was that there were only two white men working on these buildings; a carpenter and helper had been sent out a year ago by His Lordship Bishop Fleming of the Arctic, and in that short time they had trained something like 14 Indians from McPherson who were graduates of the Hay River School, to do carpenter work. At the time of my visit 10 of them were employed there, and I was amazed at the quality of work these Indians were turning out, and if anyone would have told me that these Indians had been trained in such a short time I would scarcely have believed them had I not seen them. Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on the activities of the Church of England at Aklavik:

A School has just been completed there that will accommodate probably 150 children. They also had a new Principal's house and I was informed the old Church was to be torn down and rebuilt on a larger plan. They were also working on a new hospital. As only the frame of this was up I can say very little about this building, but I was very well pleased with the arrangement of the school, and must say it was very well laid out and it will certainly meet the requirements.

What surprised me most was that there were only two White men working on these buildings; a carpenter and helper had been sent out a year ago by His Lordship Bishop Fleming of the Arctic, and in that short time they had trained something like 14 Indians from McPherson who were graduates of the Hay River School, to do carpenter work. At the time of my visit 10 of them were employed there, and I was amazed at the quality of work these Indians were turning out, and if anyone would have told me that these Indians had been trained in such a short time I would scarcely have believed them had I not seen them. His Lordship certainly sent

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report—

THAT the authorities of the Church of England in Canada have erected a building for residential school purposes in the settlement of Aklavit, Northwest Territories, to accommodate one hundred and fifty (150) children;

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines & Resources.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th instant and also copies of telegraphic communications that have passed between you and the Reverend H. G. Cook, of Fort Simpson, enclosed therewith.

I note that it is your intention to operate an Indian day school, rather than a residential school, at Hay River, on the understanding that the Department will pay per capita grant on an enrolment of 50 pupils at the Aklavik Residential School. This is the first intimation we have had of this change. We would like to have a letter indicating the exact date on which this change will take place.

I can see no serious objection to the payment of a per capita grant for 50 pupils at Aklavik, if the school at Hay River is operated as a day school and if the pupils in attendance at Aklavik are drawn from the immediate neighbourhood of the school. I cannot convince myself that the practice of transporting Indian children hundreds of miles to a residential school is a wise one. In addition to this, I am not at all satisfied with the course of instruction provided at Indian residential schools in the North West Territories. P. W. Head, M.D., Indian Agent, Fort Norman, in a letter to the Department dated July 9th, states:

"The one complaint of the Indians that I have to draw to the attention of the Department is the question of school instruction. They claim their children are taught nothing useful to them in their mode of living and that when they come home they are useless for work in the bush. Some even go so far as to state that they will not let their children return to school."

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of March 17, asking for more information regarding the industries taught in our school I reply as follows:

All girls twelve years or over have half a day in the class room and half a day in Industrial training, following these pursuits I have listed in my report. Girls younger than twelve spend the full day in the class room. The training we attempt to give them girls is as far as we are able just the sort that will be of help to them in their life after they have returned home.

All boys ten years or over receive instruction in fishing, net making and the care of nets, in season; the care of dogs, dog driving, harnessing, feeding, etc.; the handling of boats in summer; muskrat trapping in the spring, wood work, as often as much as we have opportunity, and in the procuring of firewood, water, and ice for summer water.

It is not possible to keep the boys out of school for half of each day, but they are taken in relays of twos or fours by my assistant for half a day as often as their turn comes.

I have spent eight years living in close contact with the Eskimo people on the Arctic coast, and two further years here in this settlement, and realize fully the need of practical training for these children. Judging from the children we have sent back to their homes, I think our training has been very good. Keeping the children too long a period from their homes does more harm, I think, toward unfitting them for their native life than any other factor. This needs to be watched very carefully, but with children who are orphans, who have to be taken into the school while they are still babies and have no home to go to for summer holidays, the difficulty is hard to overcome.

A native seamstress who could instruct the girls in the making and care of fur clothing, and a practical man who could instruct the boys in wood work, engines, nets, trapping and other practical things would undoubtedly help our school. I intend to take these matters up with our office in Winnipeg and see if it cannot be arranged.

I hope this answers your letter fully, and assuring
You of my earnest desire to make the training of our school as beneficial to the Eskimo and Indian peoples as possible,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

As I feel certain you and your Department will be interested in some of the worthwhile results achieved at the Schools in the Canadian northland, I am making the following extracts from a letter just received this morning from the Head Matron of our Aklavik School, and written on the 6th inst.:

"One of the older Eskimo boys of two year's schooling, and who was somewhat conversant with English before he came into residence, was able to act as an interpreter for the Police here in an emergency. We understand that both the English and the Eskimo were interpreted very well, and the boy himself was pleased to have been of service in this respect."

It will be gratifying for the former workers of both the Shingle Point and Hay River Schools to know that this summer we have received many laudable examples of the success our old Scholars are making of their time. From Cambridge Bay came written word that David, who started his schooling at Shingle Point, expected to act as organist for each of the Easter Services to be held at the Mission Church, whilst George Grover, of both Hay River and Shingle Point Schools,
"hoped to be used by the Missionary to interpret the Easter message into Eskimo for the people there.

Citing the case of Angus (Eskimo) it is understood that he was one of the most successful at White Fox trapping last year, bringing into Aklavik for trading, large catches of this valuable fur.

From Fort McPherson we learn that Peter (Indian) is his father's "right hand" - so dependable, and a Muskrat trapper in earnest.

The two pupil nurses in training here at the Mission Hospital are both from the Loucheu Band, and they give evidence of taking up their duties in a keen and praiseworthy manner. These girls Luoy and Jane have both had the advantage of School routine.

Quite proudly, Mary, coming to Aklavik a few days after her marriage at Fort McPherson to one of the former Hay River School boys, said, "Did you know that three of your old Hay River girls were married at the same time to three of the Hay River boys, and I was one of them?" We feel certain that these young people will endeavour to set up the Christian standard of living in their homes."

The statement sometimes made by badly-informed people that the Residential Schools unfit the pupils for hunting and trapping, is not supported by these quotations, and I am deeply convinced that this class of school is conferring on the Indians and Eskimo of Canada one of the greatest benefits they are receiving.

With the Season's Greetings,

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

In reply to your letter of July 2nd, and August 21st, the following is the list of the subjects taught in our class rooms, to Indian, Eskimo and half-breed children:

Reading, writing, arithmetic, health, scripture, physical training, spelling, language, history, geography, music, art, sewing, citizenship.

Particular emphasis is placed on reading, writing and arithmetic. By far the greater part of the time spent in the class room, is devoted to the teaching of these subjects. In addition to the list above noted, as much practical training as we are able to give, is given to the boys in fishing, trapping rats in season, procuring of fire wood, and all other routine work, which is a part of the living in this Northern country. The girls are taught to sew, wash, preparation of meat and fish, for meals; here we make native parkas and boots.

Most of the children who attend our school, stay for only three years, and in most cases I do not encourage them to remain longer. Exceptions have to be made in the case of orphan children. When we receive a child at nine years of age, and keep the child for three years, I consider that the child has acquired sufficient knowledge of the subjects that can be taught in our school, to give him or her, the maximum benefit of the school training, and the child is not handicapped, by this shorter period, in fitting back into their native environment.

It's clear that an extensive education can be imparted to a child in three years, but I feel that a knowledge of English and a small knowledge of school subjects, is much better than a long period away from their natural home life, and a more extensive education.
On the other hand, I would very much like to see some provision made for high education for promising boys and girls, who are mostly "white", have no home to return to, and who, given a chance, might very well develop into a much finer type of Canadian citizen, than they could possibly become with the limited opportunities available here in the North.

I trust this information will be of value to you, and anything further I can do to assist you in this survey, I will be very glad to do.

With kind regards, I am,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Archibald:

The most outstanding garden this season was at the Anglican Residential School in charge of the Reverend H.S. Shepherd. A small greenhouse constructed of storm sash and heated with a wood burning heater was used to start cabbage, cauliflower, tomato and some of the more tender varieties of flowering plants. These were all seeded during the last week of May and transplanting to the open garden was done one month later. After the cabbage, cauliflower and flowers were removed, the tomato plants were reset in the greenhouse, spaced three feet apart and allowed to remain for the season, these were producing ripe fruits by end of August and a heavy crop of large green fruits were picked September 12, when all were harvested. Transplanting of cabbage and cauliflower was quite successful and seasonal development fair, cabbage 6-7 inches and cauliflower 5-6 inches in diameter were quite common. Carrots and turnips were large and of excellent quality. The crop of Warba potatoes was exceptional, as to size, quality and yield, being quite equal to any I had seen on the trip down stream. The annual flowers also did quite well and bloomed profusely.

Your obedient servant,

The Rev. Canon Shepherd of the Indian Residential School at Aklavik, after several years of very valuable service, has felt obliged to resign.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I have your letter of April 4th, and have read Miss Corlett's report on the conditions in All Saints' Residential School. I give you herewith the following report:

Sanitary conditions and health of the pupils.

Probably the most undesirable factor in conditions began with the construction of the building itself. This building (2 storey) is constructed with class rooms, dining room, laundry and kitchen on the first floor and sleeping dormitories for both children and staff on the second floor. Due to an improper circulation of air and no doubt improper insulation in the roof, and especially due to the laundry being with the building, large amounts of moisture condensed underneath the roof. This freezes during the winter, keeps the place damp and cold and in the spring the melting of enormous quantities of ice keeps the place in a damp condition for a large period of time. I think that one of the first essentials would be the remodelling of this building to such an extent that this moisture would be eliminated. This would mean substantial changes in the construction of the roof of the building and also the removal of the laundry outside the building altogether.

With reference to the statements of Miss Corlett regarding other sanitary conditions such as drinking water, washing facilities and toilets, these, as they are, or as she states they are, are no doubt due

more......
more to carelessness in supervision than in equipment. I am sure that their equipment includes ample washbowls, soap, towels etc. They are supposedly supplied with toothbrushes and were using salt and water for cleaning their teeth. Following these complaints however, I supplied them, from our medical stores here, sufficient sodium perborate and soda bicarb. to be used as a tooth cleansing powder.

The adequacy of the food provided for the pupils enrolled and the members of the teaching staff.

My position in looking after the health of children in two schools of different denominations is such that any criticism I make of one school is no doubt used as propaganda by the other school for the procuring of children in the school. The food no doubt has been inadequate and I informed Bishop Fleming that the natives themselves all claim that the children are better fed in the Roman Catholic School than in the Anglican school, and of course to these primitive people food is taken more into consideration than schooling, sanitary conditions or anything else. However, the amount of fresh vegetables and especially fresh fruits is not nearly adequate for the number of children and staff that they have. I am sure that I personally in my own house have at least as much fresh fruit shipped in as they use in the school for about ninety children and a staff of about ten.

The amount of milk supplied is not sufficient and apparently has not been mixed to a proper strength. Very little cheese and no butter are supplied. These four essentials, fruit, milk, cheese and butter, I think are very important and should be increased.

At the present time I am developing a dairy farm here which was started with the intention of supplying at least a pint of milk per day to each child in both schools. Staff diets are also inadequate and this is an important factor where the staff with a large percentage of girls are brought in from outside and I frequently have had to treat them for neurosis no doubt due to environment and diet.

The adequacy of the fire protection and fire fighting equipment proved at the institution.

The escape shoots in the school along with proper fire drill I think is sufficient at the present time and....
and if these are not functioning properly it is again due to carelessness on the part of the staff. Outside of the school we have a fire engine and hose properly manned sufficient to handle fires in school areas. However, like many buildings constructed in the north the chimneys are of inferior build and not properly insulated. This should be very essential where they are burning as fuel spruce wood, which is full of creosote and causes many chimney fires unless pipes are cleaned very frequently.

The health of the children at the present time, and for the past several years, has been fairly good. With the exception of the two influenza epidemics this winter sickness in both schools has been small. The first year that I spent here I had a large number of deaths of school children which I attribute to a large extent to infective tonsils which undermined their general health and also was a source of continuous infection among the pupils. Since that time I have removed the tonsils of most of the children on admission or shortly afterwards and the improvement through the years has been quite marked, especially so in the lowered death rate of school children during this period.

During the past year, due to a shortage of labour, I have used two school boys to help with the routine work around my residence and farm. These boys have been staying at the school but get the majority of their meals in my house here. One of them, a boy of fourteen years of age, had a T.B. hip and had been in hospital and school for several years. The other one in hospital most of the time with very bad eyesight. These boys were put on what I considered a suitable diet of fresh meat, cows milk, cheese, butter and fresh fruit etc., and the improvement has been so marked that there is no doubt that diet to a large extent is responsible for the health of residential school children. The boy with the T.B. hip has grown and improved in all ways. The other boy, although practically unable to see, is now perfectly alright and has also grown greatly in stature during the past six months.

I might state, however, that in my medical care of the Anglican school much of my work is the care of the female staff. A great deal of the trouble is due to neurosis......
neurosis, caused no doubt to environment and diet and I would suggest that the period of four years be cut down. I think two years here is long enough for any girl.

Yours truly,

L.D. Livingstone, M.D.C.M.,
Medical Health Officer.

Dear Sir,

I wish to call your attention to three factors concerning the welfare of the Eskimo and Indian children in this, the All Saints' Residential School, Aklavik.

Two years ago I was appointed senior teacher here. Prior to that, I was on the staffs of two large towns in Alberta, and have done substitute teaching in the city of Edmonton. I have been accustomed to working among the highest of standards.

From the beginning I was appalled at the health conditions here, and set about to exercise an influence, by making the subject of health, a prominent topic in the classroom. Persistently as I endeavored, progress was stunted outside, as those in charge of the children, did not seem to consider hygienic conditions, as part of their welfare. This condition has persistently existed, in spite of my efforts to get cooperation with the Matron and Principal, both of whom agreed but whisked the affair into the background, by only a short, temporary readjustment.

I will enumerate the conditions, as I have witnessed, totally unexaggerated, most of which can be observed today.

1. The drinking pail, is a container rimmed in dirt and lying anywhere on the playroom floor. If a cup is handy, also found on the floor, it is used, otherwise the jug or pail is lifted to the individual mouth, for a draught.

2. Containers were always provided in the dormitories for excretion purposes. These were mostly left uncovered and the air became foul, the children breathing it while sleeping. This has been eradicated.

3. The toilets are smelly, with insufficient disinfectant for cleaning and no toilet paper—no paper of any kind—is ever...
provided. At Christmas I saw the children tearing up their paint books in an effort to be clean.

4. Wash bowls, soap and towels have completely disappeared in the playrooms. In other words the children are only able to wash in the morning and at night in their dormitories. Washing before meals or the classroom work begins is not observed. If, while I'm supervising the dish washing, in the dining room, a child asks to leave the room, I cannot ask him to wash his hands before returning, for there is no equipment.

5. Toothbrushes, which were given out at the beginning of the year, have completely vanished. Never has any dentifrice been given to the children. No wonder there are large dentists' bills, when no attempt is made to preserve the teeth.

6. Handkerchiefs are never provided but "nose rags" instead, which under the circumstances maybe considered more sanitary, but there are too few of them.

7. Sleep is a problem which depends on whose on duty, whether the children get to sleep at 8:30 or 10 p.m.

8. Clothes might well be described as floor mats.

9. Destruction of property due to non supervision.

These points succinctly cover the health problem. Now for the second factor—food. I am enclosing a menu—the exact contents of which I ate myself for one whole week last August—to ascertain, whether or not it was sufficient, and I can truthfully say I was hungry. The menu has been slightly changed since, milk now being given on the porridge and an extra small bowl of soup given at night. Of the one hundred dollars ($100) allowed by the government, for each child, in this school only twenty dollars and fifty two cents ($20.52) is spent on food per year, as compared to the one hundred sixty two dollars and nineteen cents ($162.19) for each staff member. That's a fact that can be proved. I studied all invoices and checked off the foods allotted to the children. This diet has been in force, since the school was established.

The most poignant problem concerning the food is that the next year's supplies have already been ordered and unless the Commission are immediately authorized to increase the diet, to a worthy standard, these children will be undernourished for another year to come. Surely the evidence is conclusive evidence of deficiency.

Is the administration of this school, bettering the welfare of these races with hygienic and food conditions, as I have described? These people are subject to tuberculosis and the diet, given here and health conditions observed, foster it. The essential products of milk, butter, eggs and cheese are denied these children.

I have no desire to turn these people into an adaptation of white man's living, but when much of their former food is being lost by the influx of population and their food habits being changed, the opportunity to teach them proper living conditions including food and hygiene should be administered from the school. There's where we fail.

The third factor concerns fire. The Commission have now become exceedingly nervous concerning the question, due to the recent losses among their school, yet they have never taken the trouble to install a proper fire alarm here. They evaded the issue by suggesting that a temporary alarm be constructed. Well its temporary alright, completely disabled now and has been for months and even when in operation couldn't be heard in all parts of the building, as cited by the experience of one staff member, who having worked nonchalantly on in her room, afterwards learned there had been a fire drill. That is just an example of how much the Commission consider of the welfare of these children.

The unprotected laundry stove pipe goes straight up through a dormitory, with a bed not three feet away. When the children fled out of there one night recently, they had to pound on a locked door to waken a staff member. Firedrill here is as rare as a sandstorm and we have only one bell to ring, the dinner bell.

I am not asking you to accept these facts without verification but I appeal to you, for the sake of these children, to request that your government representative Dr. D.H. Livingston, resident here, be authorized to enter this building and ascertain these facts.

Everyone of these facts I disclosed to the Commission last August after repeated failure to get little cooperation here, but they have taken an attitude of complacency and apathy. Other workers were asked to ascertain the food and hygienic problems last November but their resumes could only have been cursory, without any understanding of true values and since then, the Commission have refused to believe such conditions exist. If they were condemned they would blame the shortage of
dependence on native help, to which my reply is "an added atrocity", such conditions of everyday common health habits and nutrition have nothing to do with a depleted staff. I can only say I wouldn't bother crusading, if there was not a just cause.

As senior teacher, I feel that the position is one, which exercises probably the greatest influence on the future lives of these children and ultimately the race, but I have certainly been unable to forward the health problems.

One hears constant criticism, from outsiders, of course, the advisability of residential schools. Definitely it is the only way the children can be educated, but I consider the system, as it is now in force, definitely does not meet the requirements of the native. Where, in a ten month academic period, does a child get any contact with its practical life? How is a child, after a four to ten year period in a school, supposed to adapt itself to the environment of its parents, when the language, habits and arts have been severed, for such a length of time? The child is an alien and the situation is pitiful. Is that practical Christianity?

A strong indictment you say, against my own church. Definitely yes, for I fail to see how segregation from all family bonds, where language habits, customs and arts are not fostered can be called a practicing Christianity. It is contrary to the ideals of Christ's teaching.

Instead the children might well be given a seven month's intensive course, academic and practical, outlined definitely to adjust itself to their mode of living and then for the remaining five months be allowed to rejoin their parents, especially for the ratting season. During this period the school staff could go out among the people, as social service workers. This, of course would require special training, but its about time the Commission were made to realize, that non trained workers, are a menace rather than a help.

In this school there is no practical training. What the girls learn in the laundry and kitchen is incidental, there is no formal teaching. The opportunities being lost in this one school alone are heart rending.

This school and its two former foundations, Hay River and Shingle Point have been in operation for fifteen years. That seems a long period
of time, yet never has any attempt been made to further educate these children. I have taught a number of races, European and white and I know, that these children are as brilliant, as any I've ever encountered. Given a chance they could become doctors, nurses, engineers, teachers, ministers, artists or enter any trade or profession they chose and show remarkable aptitude, returning to their own field to replace the white man. One Eskimo in my classroom now, could with little training become a leading artist, of whom any country might be justly proud.

Is there no one anywhere in Canada, interested in fostering these latent talents and smothered possibilities? We have two great native races in this country but so much of their art and potentialities are being lost because of men who take only a cursory glance and administer from far off fields.

Except in length, there is no difference in the Edmonton climate and here. What a thriving city to begin an academic centre for the born leaders of two races. Why doesn't someone take a tangible interest in furthering the welfare of races, of which Canada should be justly proud?

If I have sent this letter to the wrong department, would you kindly forward it, without delay, to whichever party handles this administration. Only immediate action can be of any benefit.

Due to bereavement and financial conditions, I have been forced to resign and resume a former position but I am grieved to think I must leave these children, in the same condition I found them.

Yours very truly,

(Miss) Eden Corlett.

Aklavik Anglican Residential School

I inspected the above mentioned school on June 17th, 18th and 19th, and found that matters were proceeding in a satisfactory manner.

Miss Mary Agnes Harrington - teaches grades one and two. She holds a First Class Superior teacher's certificate for Saskatchewan, and has ten years of experience. She teaches forty residential pupils and sixteen day pupils, the classification being as follows:

| Grades | Boys | Girls |
|--------|------|-------|
|        | Ind. | Eskimo | H.B. | White | Ind. | Eskimo | H.B. | White |
| 1      | 4    | 8      | 5    | 2      | 9    | 7      |
| 2      | 6    | 2      | 1    | 4      | 6    | 1      |
|        | 10   | 10     | 5    | 1      | 6    | 15     | 8    | 1      |

Miss Harrington is a very capable teacher. The atmosphere and tone of her classroom is excellent, the pictures and decorations about the room are educational, and the children are most interested in their work. Miss Harrington makes good use of the enterprise method of instruction, and has the children working on a number of projects. She has taken some special training in woodworking, and I was able to examine a fine display of items made by the pupils, including book ends, door stops, coat hangers, tooth brush holders and so forth. This type of activity appeals particularly to the children because they have a natural bent for hand work.

I examined the work books and found them to be kept in good order. The writing was of excellent quality and the work was neatly done. The children took great enjoyment from singing, and I listened to their rhythm band.

Miss Harrington has secured a set of the new basic readers which are authorized for seven of the nine provinces of Canada. Their worth is indicated by the fact that she has been able to teach such a large class of children to read efficiently. I am of the opinion that these basic readers should be used in all the schools.
Miss Marjorie Neales - teaches grades two to eight, and holds a First Class Superior teacher's certificate from New Brunswick. She has been teaching for nineteen years, fourteen of which have been spent with Indian children. The classification of her pupils is as follows:

| Grades | Boys | Girls |
|--------|------|-------|
|        | Indian Eskimo | Indian Eskimo H.B. |
| 2      | 3    | 6     |
| 3      | 4    | 7     |
| 4      | 1    | 4     |
| 5      | 3    | 1     |
| 6      | 1    | 3     |
| 7      | 1    | 1     |
| 8      | 1    | 2     |

The discipline in her classroom is good, and she has been quite successful in adapting the Alberta school curriculum to the Northwest Territories.

Miss Neales maintains the interest and enthusiasm of her pupils. She employs the enterprise or project method of teaching, and I noticed about her classroom various projects dealing with such topics as the history of clothing, the story of transportation, and so forth. Her pupils read well and were proficient with their mathematics.

Both these teachers are of the opinion that the Dominion Government should assign to the school a definite trapping area in order that the children may be encouraged to participate in this activity.
The teachers pointed out that contrary to the viewpoint held by some residents of the Territories, children who graduate after their 15th birthday will become good trappers. A boy named David Kuliktans left school after his fifteenth birthday and succeeded in catching sixty-five white foxes during his first season of trapping. Miss Harrington states that the best hunters and trappers are former school pupils.

The staff also pointed out that because of the closed season on moose there will be no moose hides available this year. Therefore the schools are anxious that the Government provide them with moose hides in order to encourage leathercraft. It may be noted that the leathercraft industry appears to be dying out, and that the schools could play a large part in its revival. An arrangement might be worked out whereby the Government would be recompensed for the cost of the hides as the various leathercraft articles were completed and sold.

The school has recently purchased a sound film projector. Atmospheric conditions here are not suitable to radio reception. The children receive annual medical examinations and are X-rayed for T.B. They also receive dental treatments.

J. W. McKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Dear Sir,

Your First Indian School Bulletin has just reached us. It is a very real indication that the education of the Indians of our country are being considered to a greater degree than ever before. We who have tried to do our best for them are very grateful for the renewed interest from Headquarters.

You may be assured that we at Aklavik will do our best to follow the instructions of the Bulletin and look forward to the following ones with interest.

When Mr. J. MacKinnon was here we discussed the text book question and he gave us several recommendations. I had previous to his coming been teaching for some months in the classroom during a vacancy in our teaching staff. There was a dearth of texts of modern trend and what were here were so lacking in unity that I began using the Alberta Course of study. We have so far gathered numerous books for this course and are working more closely with that Department.

Our present pupilage is mainly Eskimo 60-40. Can you inform me of certain things that I have been concerned with.

In the past I have always followed my predecessors example and obtained all school supplies from the Indian Affairs Branch. Do we continue this and use the outline of texts in the Bulletin for the whole school. It would be confusion not to.

Some of the texts do not seem to be the same as recommended by the Inspector. We have had no word from him since his visit so do not know the outcome of his survey.

You see we are in quandary being responsible to two Branches of the same Department with no definite precedent to go by.

Hoping you can clear this up for me,

I remain yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Apportioning of Cost of School Material in the Northwest Territories.

We wish to advise you that the Minutes of the 169th Session of the Northwest Territories Council held on the 14th of January, 1947, read as follows:

"The arrangement is that Indian Affairs will pay the teachers' salaries and pay for text books, desks and equipment; the cost will be taken on a pro rata basis between Indian Affairs Branch and the Northwest Territories Administration".

In other words, in future, it will be necessary to indicate on all requisitions for text books, desks, etc., the number of Indians and non-Indians in attendance at the schools so that the cost of supplying such educational materials can be shared between the Indian Affairs Branch and the Northwest Territories Administration.

On 1st April we received a copy of a communication, dated 30th March, 1949, from the Northern Transportation Company (1947) Limited, 10167 - 99th Street, Edmonton, Alberta, to Rev. R. T. Gibson, Principal of our School at Aklavik, N.W.T., which reads as follows:

"During the winter months just past, we have received and stored in our warehouse at Waterways pending shipment during the 1949 navigation season, certain freight consigned to yourself at Aklavik. We now wish to remind you that this freight is stored at owner's risk of damage by fire, flood and frost."

As we had specifically instructed our suppliers that their shipments to our school at Aklavik must not reach Waterways, Alberta, before 6th May, 1949, we wired Northern Transportation Company for the names of the firms whose shipments addressed to Rev. Mr. Gibson, Aklavik, had already reached Waterways and today we received the following reply:

"We wish to acknowledge receipt of your wired request for further information on shipments at present stored in our Waterways warehouse for furtherance to the Rev. R. T. Gibson, Aklavik.

It is indeed unfortunate that you did not see fit to read and follow the instructions in the February 1, 1949 issue of the Indian School Bulletin in connection with the library books available to Indian schools.

Dear Sir,

We wish to express our thanks to your Branch for its attempt to supply us with fire protection and pressure system equipment. As you will know, through the Indian Superintendent, at Norman, the Fairbanks-Morse invoiced some items which did not arrive. We have been able to borrow a pressure tank from the R.C.O.S. and are trying to get the pressure system set up.

The Bulletin requested that we inform on any shortages in School Supplies. This has been the worst year for shortages that I have experienced. There is no need nor wisdom in trying to fill any shortages at this date due to high express rates by air but I would like you to know the following.

Invoice Dept., of Pub.P.& S. Requisition #59 335612304

4153 Multiscript Paper 3 pkgs invoiced one received.
(We may not be able to issue a school paper)
On my requisition I ordered filing folders. They were requisitioned by you but not supplied. I hope they will be forthcoming next year as my files are getting dog-eared with up to seven years use.
No exercise books came though my copy of the requisition shows some C Books ordered.
I asked for a Giant Stride Merry-go-round fitting.
We are very short on playground equipment. We purchased one ourselves for the girls and had hoped that the Dept. would supply one for the boys playground.

I am very pleased with the standard requisition form and the supplies received in the line of texts. I thank you and your Branch for its up to date attitude in this line. However we received no library books this year. The spring I was out on holiday this requisition was missed and I was reprimanded by your office for overlooking the spring requisition and ordering in December. The shoe is on the other foot. Somewhere between requisitioning and receiving there has been a slip up or loss. I think the library requisition should be traced. Shipment may have been made and lost.
Since we no longer receive shipping bills in advance we do not know what to expect.

In connection with the library requisition. We were entitled to a set of the Book of Knowledge last year and I ordered it. I hope there will be permission granted this year for it to be sent to us.

As I said before I am not asking for any mail shipment of shortages or omissions as the cost is excessive. We can manage though possibly with fewer good results and less ease.

Yours sincerely,

R.G. Gibson.

OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

From my letter to you on the 21st ultimo, you will understand my concern over the financial condition of our Commission in connexion with the administration of our Society's Indian Residential Schools. While your letter of Dec. 30th (marked "Personal") gave me some hope of receiving the grant promised for furnishings at our Aklavik School, the grant itself has not yet come to hand, and I greatly hope it may reach me in the early future.

As it is my duty as Secretary and Executive Officer of the Commission to discover either new sources of revenue, or ways of curtailing expenditures without affecting efficiency of management, I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if the government tax on gasoline used at our Schools could be either cancelled or refunded.

At the present time the tax on gasoline used at our Schools in the Province of Ontario, except that used for automobiles, is refunded, and it would afford us considerable relief if we received the same consideration from the other Provinces and territories where our Society's Schools are located. For some time the Prairie Provinces granted us exemption from this tax, but the exemption, for some reason...
or other, was cancelled some years ago, and has never been renewed.

I need hardly say that any help which you and your Department may be able to give in having this exemption restored will be highly appreciated by me and by our Commission, especially in the present time of anxiety and acute concern.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

TBRW/KH
Ottawa,
January 26, 1938.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant present regulations require our securing an Order-in-Council when making special payments to Church owned Residential Schools. I expect to secure in the near future the necessary Order-in-Council in connection with the equipment purchased for the Aklavik School. As soon as this is received payment of the grant promised will be made.

I understand that all Provinces in Canada allow a rebate of the gasoline tax when the gasoline is used for other purposes than the operation of automobiles or trucks. I believe each of your Principals can secure this rebate by making application to the Government of the Province in which the Indian Residential School is located. However, it is not possible for us to secure any rebate for gasoline used in automobiles or trucks operated by Indian Residential Schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

MINES AND RESOURCES:

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources reporting:

"THAT P.C. 740, dated April 7, 1937, established the Aklavik Church of England Indian School, Northwest Territories;

THAT this Department agreed to allow an amount of Two Thousand Dollars ($2,000.00) towards the cost of furnishing this building;

THAT funds for the above purpose were provided in the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 - Vote No. 169.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that the amount of Two Thousand Dollars ($2,000.00) be made available for furnishings for the Aklavik Church of England Indian School."

The Board concur in the above report and recommendation, and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of October 10th, 1936, No. 150-53, you authorized for our Aklavik School in the North West Territories, the engagement of a Night Watchman for seven months; namely, from October 1st of that year until April 30th, 1937, at $40.00 a month, or a total of $280.00.

Further, in your letters of September 11th and 20th, 1937, No. 150-53, you renewed the authorization for the engagement of a Night Watchman at this School for the same period, and at the same rate.

In my letter to you dated October 22, 1936, I furnished the information requested in your letter of October 10th, with regard to the method of payment of this Agent, requesting that payment be made direct to this office, in the same way that payments were to be made for our Lac la Ronge and Fort George Schools.

As no payment appears to have been made in connexion with the Aklavik appointment during 1936-37, I am enclosing herewith vouchers for the same, and vouchers for the winter months of 1937-38.

With regard to the difference in the amount paid each year by the Principal, and the amount authorized by your Department, I wish to offer the following explanation as set forth in a letter just received from the Principal of our Aklavik School, and dated January 15th last:-
"In reply to your letter re Night Watchman.

I have engaged Edgar Maring to serve as Night Watchman at the school from Nov. 1st, 1937 to March 31st, 1938 at $50.00 per month. I explained, I think, to you last year that suitable men were very scarce in Aklavik. The better class of men can earn much better wages either cutting cord wood, or trapping fur. To get around that difficulty I increased the wages last year, but shortened the time. This year I have needed to do the same thing. We do not need a Night Watchman really for October. The weather is not very severe during that month, so that the fires can be let out during the night. We do, however, need a Night Watchman for April, but no one would consent to work for wages after the Muskrat season starts"...........

"Last year I paid the Night Watchman's salary by orders on the Hudson's Bay Company's Post here. This year, since Mr. Maring has a large family and needs his salary at the end of each month, I have given him an order to one of the local traders for his salary at the end of each month. This is much the easiest way of paying accounts here where no cash is available, and mails are so infrequent".

"We have no Indian Agent nearer than Fort Simpson. If the Night Watchman's cheques could be made payable to your office, and I continue to give him an order on one of the local traders for his salary, it will simplify matters."

As the difference in the total amount you authorized, namely $250.00, has only been exceeded in the amount spent by $20.00, I trust that, under the conditions noted by the Principal, you may approve his action, and make payment accordingly.

With regard to the enclosed vouchers for the salary of the Night Watchman for the current year 1937-38, I realize that the full period has not yet expired, but as the next Air Mail from Aklavik and the far North is not due in Edmonton until April 3rd, it appeared to me to be advisable to submit the vouchers for your consideration before the expiration of the current financial year, and I trust that this action may meet with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Miss Shackleton Replies to Bishop Fleming

To the Editor of The Tribune,

Sir,—I was glad that Bishop Fleming in his letter mentioned the lighting of All Saints school at Aklavit. I only hope that the "powers" will be willing to see that plant installed. I note he is reported in The Tribune as saying that "the school plant is not under our jurisdiction but the government."

I knew the hospital and the church were under the auspices of the Diocese of the Arctic, but I was under the impression that the school building was constructed with funds supplied by the M.S.C.C. under the direction of the Inuit and Eskimo Residential school commission and even school teachers and other members of the staff were Inuit and sent to the school by that society. Hence my general reference to missionaries.

I suppose when Bishop Fleming referred to "tourist" he meant me. Well, I have never been a tourist, and I was on my job in the North as a hard-working artist, and my criticism I do not consider in the least "destructive."

Unless the whole face of nature changes in the Aklavit district (I did not refer to other parts of Northern Canada) the natives will have to earn their livelihood by trapping, hunting and fishing. To say that one has to begin when very young.

The present school curriculum as far as I see it gives no training in this direction. "Chores" learned on institutional lines are useless to people living in huts, boats and igloos. A great part of the daily routine of the school is such work on the grand scale.

My constructive suggestions were that small log cabin schools at strategic points, missionary bases, and particularly itinerant medical missionaries would be suitable for this land of water, bush, mud and muskeg.

Bishop Fleming spent many successful years travelling and living the simple life among the natives in igloos, etc. Surely he must remember that while they need what can use what the white man can give them, except the Gospel and some tips on hygiene.

As for the "white invasion" it is the native people who have to learn so much when they go "down north," how to live in the face of nature, how to dress and how to make a living. This the native can teach them.

The Bishop points out that "we have the young men who have been at our schools in Canada in employment with the Hudson's Bay Company and the government."

Natives have always worked for the H.B.C., that I know, and often I worked for the government, not because of white school training, but because of their value as experts in the field.

I still hold that the welfare of human beings, the "Temples of the Holy Ghost" is more important than having a big church building. The Gospel can be preached or lived anywhere.

KATHLEEN SHACKLETON,
Winnipeg, March 1, 1938.

"We five hundred dollars for our Aklavik School, would advise that our Commission, if allowed this sum to supplement amount they have available, can send lighting plant complete by last boat north this year -stop- As shipment must be made within ten days to connect with boat, Commission desire assurance your grant will be forthcoming -stop- Please wire reply".

As the cost of an electric light plant for the Aklavik School will be considerably more than the amount that we are providing and as the balance of the cost will be provided by the Church of England Missionary Society, I should appreciate receiving your approval to wiring Reverend Dr. Westgate that, if the Missionary Society of the Church of England purchases a lighting plant at a cost in excess of $500.00, we will allow that sum towards its cost. Dear Dr. McGill:

On the 14th inst. I sent the following Night Lettergram, charges prepaid, to Mr. Superintendent Hoey:

"REFERENCE MY LETTER MAY SIXTH YOUR REPLY MAY ELEVENTH RE GRANT FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS FOR OUR AKLAVIK SCHOOL WOULD ADVISE THAT OUR COMMISSION IF ALLOWED THIS SUM TO SUPPLEMENT AMOUNT THEY HAVE AVAILABLE CAN SEND LIGHTING PLANT COMPLETE BY LAST BOAT NORTH THIS YEAR (STOP) AS SHIPMENT MUST BE MADE WITHIN TEN DAYS TO CONNECT WITH BOAT COMMISSION DESIRE ASSURANCE YOUR GRANT WILL BE FORTHCOMING PLEASE WIRE REPLY"

Up to date I have received no reply to this message, but having heard of the serious illness of Mr. Hoey, have concluded that the delay is due to that cause.

For your information I may say that when Mr. Hoey called here on June 17th on his way back from Vancouver, I spoke to him about the grant of $500, and explained that it was not sufficient either to buy the lighting plant or the boat required for our Aklavik School, but that it would be a valuable help to us in securing the lighting plant this year if the grant could be made available to supplement what we already had on hand for that purpose. In view of the urgency of the need, and in view of the large contribution which our Commission was making for this item of equipment, Mr. Hoey expressed
the opinion that there would be no difficulty whatever in having the grant made.

As shipment had to be made immediately so as to connect with the last boat going North this summer our Commission trust that the understanding I had with Mr. Hoey may be confirmed by you, and that the grant of $500 may be forthcoming.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Principal of our Aklavik School has directed the attention of our Commission to the need of two fire escapes and two electric gongs to be used as alarms in the event of a fire.

At a meeting of the Commission's Finance Committee held here yesterday, I was instructed to ascertain if your Department could meet the cost of these items of equipment. The Principal suggested that for safety an enclosed slide is the only equipment which would provide a satisfactory emergency exit from the dormitories. One would be required at each end of the building, and it should have an approved entrance door from the building at the top, which door should be constructed so that it could never jamb with any movement of the building.

We have consulted the Winnipeg Fire Chief and leading firms in Winnipeg who manufacture the canvas slide fire escapes, but not one of them recommended such for any school. As children love toboggan slides, it was suggested at our meeting that wooden chutes might serve the purpose and I will be glad to have your opinion of the same.

At the present time a steel triangle is used as a fire alarm, and while this is sufficient during the day time, the Principal fears it might not be sufficient to awaken either staff or children when sound asleep at night.
You may recall that at the time of my last visit to Ottawa I mentioned to you and the Superintendent General the earnest desire of our Commission to have the Eskimo pupilage at this School increased from 50 to 60 and the Indian pupilage decreased from 50 to 40. It was thought at that time that the administration of the N.W.T. would soon be placed under one department of government and when that action had been taken, our request for the alteration in the pupilage would be granted. As the change has not yet been made (so far as I am aware) our per capita earnings are reduced by approximately $2,000.00 a year below what they would be if the altered pupilage were authorized.

I am furnishing you with this information in order that you may understand our Committee's desire to receive any help you may be able to give in providing the fire escapes and electric gongs.

You will be pleased to know that the Principal reports "the results of our drills to date (March 18, 1940) have given us all confidence that in the event of a fire there is already a much greater measure of personal safety for all".

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the amount of $450.00 available for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Aklavik C.E. Residential School. I note your suggestion that this amount be granted as part payment for a washer for this school. I am recommending this action to the Minister and, if he approves, I will advise you immediately.

While I advised you last August regarding the amounts available in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the schools conducted under the auspices of the M.S.C.C., it was understood, of course, that requests would be forwarded here in order that the articles required could be secured through our Purchasing Branch. We are required to follow the purchasing regulations and it makes it very difficult for us when Principals make purchases and then submit the accounts here for payment. I refer particularly in this regard to the accounts submitted for expenditures made at the Fort George School. Before a cheque can be issued I will have to obtain the Minister's approval. I feel certain that your office and the Principals of your schools will co-operate with us in this particular regard in future.

Dear Sir:

In the matter of payment of the salaries of Night Watchmen at our Society's Indian and Eskimo Residential Schools at Aklavik on the N.W.T. and Fort George in Quebec, an order was given to the respective Principals of these institutions to submit monthly requisitions for the same through the local Indian Agent. In this connection I beg to state that I have just received a letter from the Rev. Canon H.S. Shepherd, Principal of our Aklavik School, in which he points out that it is impossible for him to forward such requisitions at the end of each month because of infrequency of the mails. He also points out that by sending the requisition through the Indian Agent at Fort Norman long delays are inevitable, and reminds me that one of the requisitions he sent through the Indian Agent at Norman did not reach Ottawa until six months after it had been despatched.

Owing to the distant location of our Aklavik and Fort George Schools, and the absence of frequent mails, it has seemed to me that the most satisfactory way of dealing with the question of payment of the Night Watchmen's salaries at these Schools, will be for our Commission to submit quarterly requisitions, and in the hope and expectation that you will agree with this opinion, I am enclosing herewith requisitions in triplicate for the salary of this agent at each of the two schools mentioned, for the quarter ending December 31st last, and will send similar requisitions at the end of March next for the March quarter and the Month of April.

Should there be any further specific information which you may require in connection with these requisitions, I will gladly endeavour to supply it during my visit to Ottawa the beginning of next week.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) T.B.R. Westgate,
Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Sir:-

Re: New Batteries for Aklavik School (C. of E.)

With further reference to my letter of August 8, 1942, and the reply received from your Department on August 11, 1942, #141-1-5 (See also letter from your Department, June 30th, 1942, #160-2) re need of the above-mentioned equipment, I beg to state that Canon Shepherd, Principal of our Aklavik School has reminded me of this urgent need in a letter dated Aklavik on the 8th ultimo.

He states that the batteries now in use were bought from the "Globelite Company in the summer of 1938 and were put into service in November of that year". These batteries were "Type W-11, Capacity 210 A.H., Serial No. 6964".

He suggests that batteries with a larger capacity would be an advantage, and gives the following reasons:

"There is an average drain of 15 amperes from our plant during the six dark months, from 7 a.m. each morning until 8 p.m. in the evening. During a good part of the working hours of the day this drain increases to 20 amperes, and sometimes as high as 30 amperes. Of course we run the engine during most of each day all the winter through. Even so the batteries are worked very hard during all the dark period."

It will be appreciated if steps are taken by your Department to have these batteries forwarded by the first boat going down the Mackenzie River next summer so that ample time may
be given the staff to have them installed before the next long period of darkness begins.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, Ont., September 29, 1944.

Dr. P. E. Moore, Acting Superintendent of Medical Services, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re - Dental Services at Aklavik.

You will no doubt be interested in the attached report prepared by Dr. H. J. Mullett, covering his dental work at Aklavik this year.

As you know, the Church of England Mission arranges for a dentist to spend about two months each year at Aklavik and the Northwest Territories Council authorized a grant of $200 per annum for the work this dentist does for the school children of both the Anglican and Roman Catholic residential schools, also natives or indigent whites and half-breeds of the area. This arrangement has worked out very satisfactorily.

Encl.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner of the Northwest Territories.
The dental clinic at All Saints Hospital, Aklavik, was operated this year from June 5th to August 26th.

Aside from the excessive occlusal wear found in most of the mouths of the natives, the usual physiological and pathological conditions were in evidence among the patients visiting the clinic. The more primitive the life of the natives the better their dental condition; those who have had longer contact with so-called civilization, that is with the white man's diet and habits, have more dental caries and soft tissue disease. The work of the clinic is likely to increase with the years.

A number of impressions and models were made of interesting cases showing particular dental conditions. Certain observations may be reported later in dental literature.

The children of both the Anglican and Roman Catholic Schools were examined and the necessary treatment given, the following figures indicating the amount and type of service rendered.

Roman Catholic School

Number examined - Boys 21 (13 boys, no treatment needed)
Girls 22 (12 girls " " " )
43

16 children came to clinic for treatment.

Service rendered - 32 cement fillings
19 amalgam "
3 extractions
54 operations Fee - $98.00

Anglican School

Number examined - Boys 24 (12 boys no treatment needed)
Girls 39 (13 girls " " " )
33 students came to clinic for treatment

Service rendered - 42 cement fillings
39 amalgam "
5 silicate "
8 extractions
1 prophylaxis
95 operations Fee - $194.00
The number of cement fillings may appear to be large but they were practically all in deciduous teeth; the object being to preserve such teeth if possible for another year at least, rather than perform extractions earlier than the time when such teeth should be normally lost. The children were good patients and it was interesting working for them.

The association with all members of the mission was very happy from my standpoint. I was accepted and treated as one of the family, and I will always have pleasant memories of the three months spent with the Anglican Mission at Aklavik.

Respectfully submitted,

(signed) H. J. Mullett.

H. J. Mullett, D.D.S.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We are in serious trouble in regard to our annual supply of vegetables for All Saints' School, Aklavik, and I am writing to ask if the facilities of the Government can be extended to us to meet a real emergency.

It has been our custom to obtain vegetables from a garden north of Fort Simpson. This year we received a telegram on August 31st advising us that flood conditions had made it impossible to harvest the vegetables in time to travel by the last Hudson's Bay boat. Since then we have been in frequent communication with the grower, also with the Hudson's Bay Company and other transportation people. We had made special arrangements to charter a boat from Norman Wells in order that six tons of potatoes and carrots might have been carried to the school. This plan fell through when the Distributor met with an accident and was unable to reach Norman Wells. We have done everything in our power and now seem to have failed completely, with the result that a most difficult situation has been created at the school. A letter just to hand from Mr. J.W. Goodall of Fort Simpson, who has been doing his best for us, tells of the recent accident which befell the Distributor on Great Slave Lake, in which one barge was lost and another piled up on the shore. He tells us that Government planes have been flying in fresh vegetables, meat and other supplies to various Northern points and suggests that in such an emergency as this we may reasonably expect Government assistance in this way.

I know how difficult it is for one department to secure the cooperation of another in this way but feel that in cases where a genuine emergency arises in which human values are concerned all the resources of the state are brought into action. We are making inquiries about dehydrated vegetables and are faced with sending this material in at a very high cost. We are told that supplies are not yet available and meanwhile the needs of the children in our school will soon be acute. If any of the Government planes now operating on the Mackenzie River could take some of the vegetables now lying at Fort Simpson it would greatly relieve the situation for some time to come.
Commending this matter to your serious consideration,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A:WS

Secretary.
Ottawa, 11th October, 1945.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have your letter of the 6th instant with reference to moving vegetables and potatoes from Fort Simpson to the Aklavik C.E. Residential School.

I note your suggestion that we endeavour to secure one of the Government planes to transport some of these at least. I have discussed your suggestion with various other officials today and I cannot see any immediate prospect of assisting you.

However, our Medical Branch is endeavouring to secure a plane to transport meat from Aklavik to Fort Norman. If we are successful in securing this we will endeavour to have them take a load of vegetables from Fort Simpson to Aklavik. This movement may be delayed for a few weeks as I am informed that very few planes are flying until after freeze-up.

Yours very truly,

MR. HOEY,

The letter forwarded by Senator Haig is the same as Dr. Alderwood forwarded to us on June 6, last.

Owing to late harvest and subsequent damage to boats on the Mackenzie River, the vegetables which the M.S.C.C. purchased at Fort Simpson and intended for the Aklavik C.E. Residential School have not yet been forwarded.

When Dr. Alderwood's letter of October 6 was received, I consulted the Medical Division and was informed that they were endeavouring to secure a plane to transport reindeer meat from Aklavik to the Fort Norman Hospital. At that time it was agreed between Dr. Moore and myself that if a Transport Plane could be secured the vegetables could be taken from Fort Simpson to Aklavik and the meat brought back from Aklavik to Norman.

I spoke to Dr. Moore again this morning about the matter and he states that it has been impossible to make arrangements for plane service, although he has enlisted the co-operation of Director R. A. Gibson and also made another approach to the R.C.A.F. As the matter stands, no definite arrangements have been made for a plane and it is doubtful when these arrangements can be satisfactorily effected.

Philip Phelan,

re Labour at All Saints' School, Aklavik

I have been a long time in securing the completion of the Labour Returns you kindly gave me when last in your office. It was necessary to send these to Aklavik for the signature of the Principal and they have just been returned.

Perhaps I should explain that we found it necessary to have a skilled carpenter at Aklavik to attend to two important pieces of work. The school roof was leaking badly and much damage was being done. We were advised that while rough carpentry work could be done by local help there was no-one with the expert knowledge to carry out the scientific roof construction which appeared to be necessary. We also decided to build a joint power-house and laundry building to serve both school and hospital. This took the condensation from the laundry out of the school and also effected economy and efficiency by pooling the mechanical equipment. The school lighting plant had been breaking down and we are now securing new items for the combined work, with former equipment in reserve in case of emergency.

It was necessary to incur heavy expense in sending the builder in and bringing him out by plane so that he should have as much time as possible to do the work. In view of these facts, I trust that you may be able to give us assistance with the labour cost.

It is understood that your Departmental appropriations for the current year include $1,000 for the Church of England Indian Residential School at Aklavik.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Essential Services, 1948-49
All Saints Indian Residential School, Aklavik

As you have certain amounts in your 1947-48 Departmental Estimates for miscellaneous services at our Church-owned Schools, I presume that you will make similar provision when preparing your estimates for 1948-49.

We have just received the enclosed from the Principal of our Aklavik School in response to a request for a statement of the services most urgently needed there. I would be glad if, on the basis of this, you would make as generous provision for this School as you can in your 1948-49 estimates.

Will you please advise me, at your convenience, of the amount you propose to provide so that we may give consideration to finding the balance needed for essential services there.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent
Dr. H. A. Alderwood,
Superintendent,
Indian School Administration, M.S.C.C.,
Bank Street Chambers,
102 Bank Street, Ottawa, Ontario,

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your telegram of Sept. 25 I am enclosing a list of requirements under headings given.

Data for cost is hard to get on short notice. There may be a plane in this week end. The list is skeleton in form and I will endeavour to supply more information in the following paragraphs.

New Building Construction.
In spite of the fact that you believe this school to be large in comparison to some we find ourselves very crowded with the addition of a third classroom. The original plans for the school had an additional sketch of a wing out from the back of the boys side to be used as a play room for the boys. The present playroom was intended as a classroom.

New Heating Water Supply etc.
Furnace (J.P.H.) This is on order from Winnipeg Paint and Glass but did not come through. You have specifications? I have not.
The enlarging of the basement $50 will be for dressed lumber obtained locally for shoring the walls.
The jacket heater was also requisitioned, specifying that it must heat water to laundry temperature and have flat surface for boiler. The hot water tank another item on requisition was to accompany the jacket heater. A capacity of at least 60 gals.
Electric pump (J.P.H.) We have an electric pump in the school.
There has been an initial request for a pressure system for the school from before my time. We have not pressed the matter as there were other things more urgent. However for fire protection and convenience this would be desirable. Should a pressure system be installed at the school a transfer of our present pump to the J.P.H. could be arranged; If no pressure system is forthcoming a second pump is needed for the laundry.
I specify Wesco. The hospital has a Westco pump and there is only one moving part.

Gasoline Operated Extractor. We requested this before but were turned down. We know they must be expensive.
I asked for a wooden tank to replace the one moved to the J.P.H., which left us with a supply used in less time than is convenient to pump in cold weather. We have gone as long as ten days melting ice because we could not pump. If fire occurred at such time we would be helpless.
MAJOR REPAIRS TO BLDGS.

Painting. I requisitioned paint. Did not even hear if it was ordered.
The roofing paper came. The 30 barrels of tar are somewhere between here and Werway. I received shipping bill but no invoice price.
The freight alone is $1350.
The roofing alone will not cure the frost. The new ceiling material referred to are at Eaton's prices.
The fire escapes are far from comfortable and are getting out of repair.

Major repairs to installations.
The wire running from the pow r house to the school is too light.
The fire boxes of our furnaces have cracked and are a menace to safety.
New boxes or some extensive repair must be done.
The battery plate on one set of batteries are beginning to fall apart.

Major Repairs to heavy equipment.
We requisitioned for repairs to the tractor, but nothing came.
The front tires for it are shot.
The axle was broken before I came. We have to tear it down at least once a year and patch it up with more bracing.

Two copies of this are being sent to you in case one must go to the Arctic Office.

Hoping that what I have given is sufficient.

Yours sincerely,

R.G.

It has been difficult to know where to place the items as much is necessary yet we have been getting along in a sort of way without them. Much criticism come upon me from the staff for not having certain things done on time, no playground equipment made for the children and so on. But the whole thing results from the fact that as we have no labour saving devices we must all work at chores.

R.G.
Ottawa, November 7, 1947.

Re: Indian Residential Schools - Aklavik, Northwest Territory and Carcross, Yukon

Further to your letter of September 22 relative to the possibility of your making an inspection of the two Indian Residential Schools at the places noted above, the information contained in your letter has been given verbally to Mr. Neary, Superintendent of Education, in the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, and he has been informed that your expenses of making these trips and preparing the valuation of the various buildings would have to be paid by the Indian Affairs Branch. He has agreed to this procedure and has stated that when you forward your expenses for these trips, his branch will make the necessary payments to the Department of Public Works.

I enclose for your information, copy of letter, dated September 24, from Mr. Neary to this office, to which is enclosed a letter, dated September 13, from the Superintendent of Anglican Mission Schools to Mr. Neary, giving certain information as to the school buildings at Carcross.

I also enclose copy of letter, dated September 22, relative to the plans of the schools at Aklavik, N.W.T., to which is attached blue prints of that particular building.

The Anglican Missions have provided the following information:

Aklavik Building - Built in 1935 at a cost of $55,750.00
Carcross Building - Built in 1944 at a cost of $24,215.45

Information in this office is not clear as to whether these costs will be the cost of the school building only, or whether they will be costs of other related buildings used by the Anglican Missions at each particular place. This question should be clearly established when you visit each particular site, so that in making your report it will be quite clear that you are valuing the school building only.

The Indian Affairs Branch have the necessary funds to make the purchases of these schools, and I am informed that they are most anxious to conclude these transfers during the present fiscal year. If it would be possible for you to make the necessary inspections and prepare the valuations in the next two months, it would be appreciated.

I am forwarding copy of this memo to Mr. Neary of the Indian Affairs Branch for his information, and requesting him to write to the Indian Agent at each place concerned, so that those officials will have knowledge of your impending trip.

When making your report, it is requested that you return the blue prints as they are the only ones received from the Indian Affairs Branch.

Gustave Breault,
Chief Architect.
