Dear Sir:

Re: Anglican Residential School - Aklavik, N.W.T.

The following is a report and valuation of the Anglican Residential School at Aklavik, N.W.T.:

The building was erected in 1936, the work being carried out by native labour under the direction of a skilled carpenter foreman, sent in from Eastern Canada.

The building is well constructed and is in a fairly good state of repair.

The foundations consist of wooden posts sunk 8' 0" into the ground, capped with beams on which the joists are laid.

There is really no basement except the space left under the first floor, by the natural fall of the ground. However, passageways have been excavated to give access to the different parts of the basement, which is used for storage purposes. Floors are earth.

The building is of frame construction and conforms very closely to the details shown on the plans. Framing lumber is spruce, finished lumber and floors, fir.

As is common with buildings in these parts, which are built on permanent frost, considerable settlement has taken place in the interior of the building, although there has been very little on the outside walls. Two years ago the beams were all jacked up level, packing put on top of the original posts, new posts installed on new mud sills and the building is now level, although some of the beams under the second floor show a slight sag.

The interior walls and ceilings are covered with tentest, painted, and are in a good state of repair, with the exception of the ceiling to the second floor. When the building was erected, the insulation was placed between the rafters instead of between the ceiling joists, with the result that considerable condensation took place, which melted onto the ceiling. It is intended to replace this ceiling and material is on hand to carry out this work next summer.
The floors are of fir and are showing signs of wear, particularly in the dormitories. The corridors and a few of the rooms are covered with inlaid linoleum. Floors should be covered with battleship linoleum before long.

Plumbing: There is no water or sewer system in Akivik. Sanitary chemical closets are used by the staff, and are available for the children in severe weather. Otherwise the children use outside toilets.

Water for washing etc., is obtained from the river, being pumped periodically into the wooden storage tanks in the basement, capacity, 3,000 gals. From these tanks it is passed into galvanized iron tanks on the floor, above from which it is drawn off and carried by hand to the different parts of the building. Drinking water is obtained by melting ice.

Heating: The building is heated with forced circulation, hot air through exposed ducts on the ceilings. There are two furnaces, as shown on plan "Economy No. 25 for Wood" manufactured by Peace Foundry, Toronto, each with its own system of ducts and circulating fan. The furnaces rest on concrete foundations carried on posts entirely separate from the foundations of the building. Flues are of steel and are well insulated where passing through floor and roof. Approximately 200 cords of wood are used in a year and consideration is now being given to the use of coal, which can be obtained from a mine some 40 miles away.

Electrical: Electric power is obtained from the Missions' own power plant and is 110 Volt direct current. Service consists of two main 40 amp. switches, one for each floor. Wiring is installed in flexible conduit, exposed on ceilings and walls and I am told has been installed by the Radio Operator. Additional wiring has been run, direct from the plant, to take care of electrical equipment, such as bread mixer, pumps, etc., which have been added later. The service is fully loaded now and any additional load placed on the existing wiring, would in my opinion constitute a danger.

The building should be rewired in rigid conduit in accordance with the Canadian Electrician Code, as soon as possible. At the same time, I would suggest that consideration be given to obtaining power from the Settlement Power Plant, which would provide alternating current, instead of direct. This would make possible the use of fluorescent lights.

Fire fighting equipment consists of 8 - 2½ gal. Fire Extinguishers, 7 small Pyrene Extinguishers and 20 Fire Extinguishers Bombs.

The exterior of the building is in good repair. It was painted five years ago and paint is on hand to paint the whole of the exterior this summer. A new five ply felt and pitch roof was put on last summer, materials being obtained from Edmonton and installed by local labor, in accordance with the directions given by manufacturer.

I find the Administrative Building, which is in course of construction for the Government, is costing approximately $1.25 a cubic foot. On this basis, I estimate the replacement value of the School Building at $1.10 a cubic foot.

Replacement value 182,000 cubic feet @ $1.10 = $200,200.00

Depreciation at 2½% per annum
30% of $200,200.00 = $60,600.00

Cost of rewiring building, replacing second floor ceiling and other minor work required to bring building up to standard. $15,000.00

Present day value $124,600.00

I could get very little information regarding the value of land. Mr. Bouchard, Government Administrator, informed me there was no assessment of land and that it was practically worthless. He said a nominal sum of $25.00 was placed on lots. There was no one at the School who could give me any information on this subject, but it was presumed that there would be no difficulty in having a portion of the Mission property, on which the school building stands, transferred to the Government, in the event of the school building being purchased.

With reference to other Mission Buildings, as far as I could ascertain, the school building is the only building being considered in this transaction. The above valuation is for the school building alone.

Dear Doctor Keenleyside,

Please refer to your letter dated April 3 relative to inspection and valuation of the buildings of the Church of England Indian Residential School at Aklavik, N.W.T. Your letter requests information as to the value of the principal's residence, two ice houses, a warehouse and a workshop building.

This matter was referred to the District Resident Architect at Victoria who made the original valuation on the Indian School Building and, for your information, I enclose a copy of his report dated April 14, 1949. You will note from the report that Mr. Wells did make an inspection of these buildings and in his report states:

"When I stated in my report that I had inquired whether any other buildings were to be included in the transaction it was buildings such as mentioned above that I had in mind, not the outbuildings to the school such as the outside toilets and the store buildings mentioned.

While these buildings were not specifically mentioned in my report, their relative value being so small, it was my intention that the valuation which I put on the building (school building) should cover these buildings, that is the outside toilets, the ice houses and the warehouse as they are obviously necessary for the operation of the school and practically valueless apart from it."

The District Resident Architect has stated in his report he considers the workshop building a fair and reasonable value at $1,000.00

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian School - Aklavik, N.W.T.

With reference to the valuation which I made of the Anglican Indian Residential School, Aklavik, N.W.T., and the request now being made for valuations of other buildings in connection with the above mentioned building, I beg to report as follows:

While in Aklavik, I visited all the buildings of the Church of England Mission, the powerhouse, hospital, cathedral, Canon's residence, Principal's Residence, etc., and while I did not examine them in detail as I did the school, I can state that all the buildings of the Mission are well maintained and are in a good state of repair.

When I stated in my report that I had inquired whether any other buildings were to be included in the transaction it was buildings such as mentioned above that I had in mind, not the outbuildings to the school such as the outside toilets and the store buildings mentioned.

While these buildings were not specifically mentioned in my report, their relative value being so small, it was my intention that the valuation which I put on the building should cover these buildings, that is the outside toilets, the ice houses and the warehouse as they are obviously necessary for the operation of the school and practically valueless apart from it.

I did not include the workshop. I visited this building and I consider $1,000.00 a fair and reasonable valuation of it.

The Principal's residence is a storey and a half building comprising six rooms, three rooms and bath room on first floor and two rooms on second floor with a porch on front and shed at back. The building is in good repair and comprises approximately 1200 cubic feet.

My valuation of present day value is 1200 cubic feet at .80¢ a cubic foot - $960.00, which I consider fair and reasonable.

Yours sincerely,

L.S.W. Wells,
Architect

December 5, 1936.

For information of the Indian Department.

The District Agent
Fort Smith, N.W.T.

Dear Sir,

I acknowledge with thanks a supply of quarterly return forms #61 received from your office during the summer.

I am sending you under separate cover:

1. Return forms #61 in triplicate for all Eskimo and half-breed children in the school.
2. Admission and discharge forms #78 in triplicate for the same.
3. Applications forms #77 in triplicate for all Eskimo and half-breeds in the school except two.
4. Return forms #403 for all Treaty Indians in the school.
5. Admission and discharge forms #411 in duplicate for the same.
6. Applications form #77 in triplicate for all Treaty Indians in the school.

I am not sending application forms for those children transferred from Hay River and from Shingle Point. I didn't think it necessary. The two others I have mentioned above as not having sent, have yet to be signed by their respective fathers. I shall get the signatures and send them along next mail.

I have used form #77 for Treaty Indians because the proper form did not come to hand until near the end of September when the forms were already filled up. I have marked in each case "Treaty Indian" at the top of each form.

If I have not sent copies enough of these forms advise me and I shall send as many as you need in the future. I have sent a copy of all forms except application forms to the Indian Residential School Commission, Winnipeg.

I should like a further supply of forms #411 only, if you please.

Yours very truly,

'sgd' H. SHERMAN SHEPHERD,
PRINCIPAL.
4th March, 1937.

Memorandum.—

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources.

Ref. - All Saints Residential School -
Aklavik.

Attached is a copy of a letter dated the 5th December last, addressed to our District Office, Fort Smith, by Reverend H. S. Shepherd, Principal of All Saints Anglican residential school - Aklavik. Also enclosed are the forms mentioned in this letter dealing with Treaty Indian children now in residence.

ENCL.

R. A. Gibson,
Director.
Ottawa, March 10, 1937.

Rev. Sir:

The Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs, of the Department of Mines & Resources, has forwarded to this Branch a copy of your letter dated December 5th, last, submitting quarterly returns and applications for admission and discharge of pupils at the Aklavik C. of E. Indian Residential School. The Department approves the admission of each of the Treaty Indian children covered by these applications.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of the March quarter return of the Aklavik C. E. Residential School and the admission of Julia Stewart and Sally Ezai is approved. As we only require one copy of the application forms the duplicates are returned for your file. I am returning the admission and discharge sheet in order that you may revise it. The top part of this form should only show the names of the pupils admitted to the school for the first time during the quarter. The bottom part of the return should only show the names of the pupils who have been finally discharged from the school and returned to their homes.

James Husby, No. 9, was admitted to the Aklavik School in the year 1936. Apparently he was ill in hospital for some time but is still a pupil of the school. His name should not have been included on the admission and discharge form. All that was necessary in his case was to make a note opposite his name on the quarterly return showing the date he was admitted to hospital and the date he was discharged. As you are aware grant is not allowed for pupils when they are in hospital as the Department is responsible for their hospital expenses.

From the information given in this letter I would appreciate if you would prepare and forward a revised admission and discharge form for the March quarter.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the Treaty Trip just concluded I beg to report that in company with Mr. W. Pugh of the Edmonton Agency we proceeded from the Resolution Indian Agency on the morning of July 1st.

FORT MC PHERSON

A strong protest was placed against the recruiting by the Missions of the Indian children to the schools. The Indians stated that the missions took their children to school in the fall but did not return them in the spring. This entailed a trip to Aklavik in the summer to see their children or else a prolonged visit in Aklavik, at a considerable expense. They do not like this as when they arrived in Aklavik they followed the usual Indian inclination to hang around a white settlement to their own detriment. On arrival in Aklavik and upon further enquiry this was found to be the case. The matter was discussed with the Anglican and R.C.Missions and am pleased to report that they are both going to take the school children to McPherson and Arctic Red River during the 1939 summer holidays. Copies of letters received from Indians attached, dealing with this matter. I would judge that Aklavik as an Indian rendezvous should be discouraged. However this will be a difficult problem.

Dr. J.P. Harvey,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The Treaty Indian child described on the attached form was seen by me while on the Treaty trip in July, and the particulars made clear.

In Sept. 1936 the mother died in the R.C. Hospital at Aklavik. Prior to this the father explaining straightened circumstances, asked the Anglican Mission to care for his child. They did so and have continued to do so.

The father has tried repeatedly to find a home for the child with no success and has been able to pay only thirty dollars toward his support.

Considering the case of the child and his father's apparent inability to do much toward his keep, and that the Residential School has already looked after him for two years, it would seem reasonable that the child should be put on the list of those resident there and counted in those for which Department grant is made.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir:

In checking the December quarter return of the Aklavik C.E. residential school we find the name of Maria Bonnetplume as No. 03. The last time this girl's name was shown on the return was for the quarter ended June 30, 1937, at which time she was stated to have been sent to hospital. No. 022 on the December return is also shown as Maria Bonnetplume and it is stated that she entered the school during the September quarter of 1938. Is this a different girl from No. 03 or was a mistake made in preparing the return by including this girl's name twice?

Dear Dr. Westgate:

We were instructed by wire by both the Indian and Interior Departments to make up the March Quarterly Returns to the day that the mail left. We did this, which left five days remaining on that quarter. I enquired from Dr. Livingstone what we should do about these five days and he advised me to make separate returns and send them in when I could. There is a special plane in today, which will be the last possible mail plane until June. I am therefore sending all the forms to you, and shall ask you to send on three copies to the Department of Interior and the usual procedure and one copy to the Department of Indian Affairs, retaining one of each for your own file. If I should send these to the Agents at Norman and Fort Smith they could not possibly reach you outside until some time in June.

Faithfully yours,

(Sgd) H.S. Shepherd,
Principal.

Re. No. 12 Thomas Ross

Dear Sir,

I find from the school records that Thomas Ross was given leave of absence on March 1st, 1940 for the ratting season. In the quarterly return for that quarter a note is made to that effect. I find that his parents came for the boy and promised to return him at the end of the ratting season. At the end of the season the family were at their camp fifty miles from the settlement, and could not return the boy. Since then the mother of the family has become ill, and since the boy is of use about the house I expect he shall not return to the school.

Yours truly,

February 5, 1941.

J.P. Harvey,
Indian Agent,
Fort Norman N.W.T.

Dear Sir,

I expect we shall have several boys out this year for the ratting season. This means that they go away early in March and are away until June 15th, or after that date. In the case of some who are in far away parts of the Delta the child cannot be returned to school before the end of the term. This I consider a good thing since it keeps these older boys in touch with their native life. However they are absent from the school for the whole of one quarter and as the matter stands the school loses the grant for that period. I believe the Department desire the older children to be allowed to leave the school for the ratting season and we have no objection to their going except that it does not seem right that we should lose the grant for six or eight children for three months.

I would be glad if you would give me a ruling in the matter; whether or not they are to be allowed to go, and in the event of their going how the grant is to be reckoned.

Yours faithfully

[Signature]
Principal

I am advising Canon Shepherd, the Principal of this School, of the substance of your letter, but I am not convinced that the delays you mention are due to neglect on his part. Dear Mr. Hoey:

With regard to the delay in receiving quarterly returns from our Aklavit School as referred to in Departmental letter of September 5th last, 141-1-10, and your letter to me on the 17th of September, I beg to state that I wrote to the Principal of this school in this important matter, and have recently received from him the following information:

In a letter dated September 20th he wrote, in part, as follows:

"I sent the original of the March quarterly returns direct to the Indian Agent at Fort Norman...... Because I heard nothing from it, I presumed all had worked out well, and sent the original of the July quarterly returns through the same channel. I mailed the copies for the March quarter on April 12th and for the July quarter on July 26th.

"I have made it a point to get those quarterly returns away on the first possible mail after the close of each quarter. With the September quarter there must be a long delay since we never get a mail from about the middle of September until Christmas time in each year. In the spring there is sometimes a long delay depending on whether or not we get a mail in April. If the weather continues cold we often do; if it does not then there is no mail after the March aeroplane until June. The returns for the other two quarters can always be sent away fairly promptly."
Principal Shepherd suggests that to avoid further delays in the receipt of his returns, he be allowed to ask the Medical Officer of the Department of Mines and Resources to sign the returns, and that they be mailed direct to you thereafter, instead of being sent through the agency at Fort Norman. I will be obliged if you will let me know if this arrangement has the approval of your branch of Government.

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Doctor Westgate:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant the Department allows 62 days holiday leave with grant. Consequently, for a pupil who goes on leave on June 30 and returns on September 1 grant should be requested on the September quarter return for 92 days. In the case of a pupil who goes on leave on June 30 and does not return until September 15 grant should be requested for 77 days. In brief, when preparing the September quarter return grant should be requested, in the case of those pupils who were in the school on June 30, for the exact number of days they were in residence during the September quarter plus 62 days holiday leave for which grant is allowed.

The Department would appreciate anything you can do to impress upon the Principal of the Aklavik Residential School the importance of transmitting his quarterly return immediately following the close of the quarter.
